From 1930 to 1934 he attended art classes at the Escuela de artes y oficios in Granada, and in 1940, following his friend Federico Garc\u00eda Lorca\u2019s advice, he moved to Madrid, where he continued his studies at the Escuela superior de bellas artes de San Fernando (now Real academia de bellas artes de San Fernando). On completing art school in 1945, Guerrero received a grant from the French government to study fresco painting for one year at the \u00c9cole des beaux-arts, Paris, where he experienced firsthand the works of Juan Gris, Joan Mir\u00f3, and Pablo Picasso, and became particularly interested in those of Henri Matisse. The landscapes and rural scenes Guerrero painted on his return to Spain reflect Matisse\u2019s profound influence on his work.\nStarting in 1946 Guerrero embraced the life of a wanderer and spent several years traveling across Europe, staying in Bern, Brussels, London, Paris, and Rome. In Rome he befriended Afro (Afro Balsadella) and his brother Mirko (Mirko Balsadella), and he met Roxanne Whittier Pollock, the American journalist he would marry in 1949. This same year, the couple moved to the United States, staying in Philadelphia first and settling in New York a year later.\nThis move opened a new course in the artist\u2019s work. Guerrero painted his last figurative work, a self-portrait, in 1950. Thereafter, galvanized by Abstract Expressionism, he abandoned his figurative style for abstraction. Characteristic of this new phase, simplified, biomorphic forms float in a quasi-monochromatic background. By the mid-1950s Guerrero\u2019s style had become more gestural, expressing a deeper sense of urgency, as he loosened his brushstroke and introduced a controlled dripping technique. A selection of these new paintings appeared in an exhibition at Betty Parsons Gallery, New York, in 1954, marking Guerrero\u2019s emergence as a distinctive painter within the New York school. Since moving to New York, Guerrero had become acquainted with some of the most prominent members of the American avant-garde including Willem de Kooning, Franz Kline, Robert Motherwell, Mark Rothko, and Theodoros Stamos. Concurrently he met James Johnson Sweeney, critic and director of the Guggenheim Museum, who included his work in Younger American Painters: A Selection (1954).\nIn 1965 Guerrero returned to Spain and from then on divided his time between his native country and the United States. Coinciding with Guerrero\u2019s return to Spain is the reintegration of purer colors in his works, distant from the anxiety-ridden, predominantly black paintings of the late 1950s. Throughout the 1970s and 1980s, Guerrero\u2019s abstract style continued to evolve, as he created orderly and rhythmic vertical compositions, followed by increasingly dynamic works in which brilliant hues took the lead.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Granada", "artistBirthDate": "1914", "artistDeathDate": "1991"}}, "171": {"paintingDate": "2006", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/2011.65_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on canvas", "paintingName": "Untitled (Blue Painting Light to Dark X)", "paintingNo": 171, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Mark Grotjahn", "artistBirthCountry": "California", "biography": "Mark Grotjahn was born in 1968 in Pasadena. He received a BFA from the University of Colorado, Boulder (1990), and an MFA from the University of California, Berkeley (1995). In his paintings and works on paper, Grotjahn collapses the seemingly opposed painterly modalities of abstraction and figuration into a singular and visually dynamic artistic gesture. At once formally taut and emotionally charged, his works condense a range of art-historical influences, creating an instantly recognizable oeuvre.\nWhile traditionally abstraction is thought of as a reductive strategy, intended to strip painting of its illusionistic quality in order to emphasize the picture plane itself, for Grotjahn the investigation into the phenomenology of painting is anything but restrained. Indeed, the artist invokes a brash Expressionism to expose the perspectival idiosyncrasies of two-dimensional space. This bravado can be seen clearly in his two best-known bodies of work, his Butterfly paintings (1997\u2013\u00a0) and Face series (2009\u2013\u00a0). In each case Grotjahn continually iterates a fixed motif in order to mount a sustained investigation of widely-held ideas of symmetry, perspective, form, and, ultimately, authorship. Growing out of a body of work loosely known as perspective drawings, Grotjahn\u2019s Butterfly works employ the motif of the radiant band to explore the notion of Renaissance perspective. Seemingly splayed open like the wings of a butterfly, these canvases contain two or more vanishing points set along a vertical band. The rays that emanate from these points are colored in neatly, yet the viewer is never oriented within the canvas. The Face paintings, on the other hand, do not betray such a systematic approach but rather point to the artist\u2019s process. Loose and gestural in appearance, these paintings are composed of sinewy ropes of impasto laid on top of cardboard mounted on linen. In each, a primitively rendered face anchors the canvas, referencing Pablo Picasso\u2019s investigation of perspective in the years leading to his iconic Les demoiselles d\u2019Avignon (1907). \nPicasso\u2019s influence also underlies Grotjahn\u2019s Mask series (2012\u2013\u00a0). These bronze sculptures, which recall anthropological artifacts, are cast from cardboard models and then painted by Grotjahn with his fingers in a seemingly haphazard fashion. Although these works represent his first public foray into three dimensions, Grotjahn has in fact been making the cardboard models that provide the armature of these masks for many years. As in many of his paintings, the artist\u2019s name is embedded within the surface of several sculptures, bringing to the fore an assertion of authorship as a complicating factor. By insisting on the use of an immediately identifiable style as an ersatz signature and simultaneously submerging his literal signature within many of his works, Grotjahn problematizes the slipperiness of the authorial gesture in contemporary art. \n", "artistBirthPlace": "Pasadena", "artistBirthDate": "1968", "artistDeathDate": ""}}, "170": {"paintingDate": "1917", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/38.238_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on wood panel", "paintingName": "Fruit Dish on a Checkered Tablecloth", "paintingNo": 170, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Boulogne-sur-Seine", "artistDeathCountry": "France", "artistName": "Juan Gris", "artistBirthCountry": "", "biography": "Juan Gris was born Jos\u00e9 Victoriano Carmelo Carlos Gonz\u00e1lez-P\u00e9rez in Madrid on March 23, 1887. He studied mechanical drawing at the Escuela de Artes y Manufacturas in Madrid from 1902 to 1904, during which time he contributed drawings to local periodicals. From 1904 to 1905 he studied painting with the academic artist Jos\u00e9 Maria Carbonero. In 1906 he moved to Paris, where he lived for most of the remainder of his life. His friends in Paris included Georges Braque, Fernand L\u00e9ger, and Pablo Picasso and the writers Guillaume Apollinaire, Max Jacob, and Maurice Raynal. Although he continued to submit humorous illustrations to journals such as L'Assiette au beurre, Le Charivari, and Le Cri de Paris, Gris began to paint seriously in 1910. By 1912 he had developed a personal Cubist style.\nHe exhibited for the first time in 1912 at the Salon des Ind\u00e9pendants in Paris, Galeries Dalmau in Barcelona, Der Sturm gallery in Berlin, the Salon de la Soci\u00e9t\u00e9 Normande de Peinture Moderne in Rouen, and the Salon de la Section d'Or in Paris. That same year D.H. Kahnweiler signed Gris to a contract that gave Kahnweiler exclusive rights to the artist's work. Gris became a good friend of Henri Matisse in 1914 and over the next several years formed close relationships with Jacques Lipchitz and Jean Metzinger. After Kahnweiler fled Paris at the outbreak of World War I, Gris signed a contract with L\u00e9once Rosenberg in 1916. His first major solo show was held at Rosenberg's Galerie l'Effort Moderne in Paris in 1919. The following year Kahnweiler returned and once again became Gris's dealer.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Madrid", "artistBirthDate": "1887", "artistDeathDate": "1927"}}, "182": {"paintingDate": "2014", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/2014.29_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Acrylic,  oil,  spray paint,", "paintingName": "Landscape with Pyramids", "paintingNo": 182, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Federico Herrero", "artistBirthCountry": "Costa Rica", "biography": "Federico Herrero was born in San Jos\u00e9, Costa Rica, in 1978, and studied painting at the Pratt Institute, New York, from 1997 to 1998. Since 2001, he has undertaken commissions in Canada, Costa Rica, Japan, Sweden, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom.\nHerrero\u2019s practice stands outside Latin America\u2019s Conceptual, muralist, and geometric abstraction traditions, yet his work references all of these styles. Herrero\u2019s images are often populated by patches of color, alien-like figures, and disembodied eyes, and reveal a fascination with crossing boundaries. The artist blurred the line between public and private, for example, in an intervention titled Fictional Publicity (2000), in which he hung small paintings all over his native city; some remained in place for days, others vanished after just a few minutes. For the Havana Biennial (2003), Herrero transgressed national borders by painting mappa mundi at the bottom of a public pool, allowing Cuban swimmers to imagine themselves roaming the globe.\nHerrero also questions the spatial boundaries of museum and gallery interiors, taking an installation-like approach to the presentation of his work in such contexts. The artist\u2019s 2008 exhibition at Kunstverein Freiburg, Germany, for example, paired conventional paintings on canvas with stripes and patches of color painted directly onto the interior architecture. The artist\u2019s fascination with limits is evident, too, in the canvases\u2014small bubbles of bright color sometimes peep from behind the primary subject, as in Blue Mountain (2008), or seem to stare curiously at the viewer, as in Green Landscape with Nine Circles (2008). Herrero\u2019s work is essentially a study of liminal spaces\u2014gaps between figure and background, canvas and wall, private and public, and (perhaps most significantly) between work and viewer. The forms and colors in his paintings also capture the energy of urban Costa Rica and its vibrant tropical setting.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "San Jos\u00e9", "artistBirthDate": "1978", "artistDeathDate": ""}}, "183": {"paintingDate": "2014", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/2014.28_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Since 2001, he has undertaken commissions in Canada, Costa Rica, Japan, Sweden, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom.\nHerrero\u2019s practice stands outside Latin America\u2019s Conceptual, muralist, and geometric abstraction traditions, yet his work references all of these styles. Herrero\u2019s images are often populated by patches of color, alien-like figures, and disembodied eyes, and reveal a fascination with crossing boundaries. He entered the Institut Industriel du Nord in Lille to study chemistry in 1920 but left the following year to become an architectural apprentice in Paris. He painted while working as an architectural draftsman in the early 1920s. H\u00e9lion attracted the attention of the collector Georges Bine in 1925 and was soon able to devote himself entirely to painting. In 1927 he met Joaqu\u00edn Torres-Garc\u00eda, who collaborated on L'Acte, a short-lived magazine founded by H\u00e9lion and others.\nH\u00e9lion first exhibited at the Salon des Ind\u00e9pendants in 1928. Shortly thereafter he became acquainted with Jean Arp, Piet Mondrian, and Antoine Pevsner. By 1929 his work was nonfigurative. With Theo van Doesburg and others in 1930 he formed the artists' association Art Concret and the periodical of the same name. This group was succeeded by Abstraction-Cr\u00e9ation the next year. In 1931, after traveling through Europe and the Soviet Union, H\u00e9lion returned to Paris, where he met Marcel Duchamp, Max Ernst, and Tristan Tzara. His first solo show was held at the Galerie Pierre in Paris in 1932. That same year H\u00e9lion made his first visit to New York, where he was given a solo exhibition at the John Becker Gallery at the end of 1933. After returning to Europe from a second trip to the United States in 1934, he met Jacques Lipchitz, Joan Mir\u00f3, and Ben Nicholson. In 1936 he settled in the United States, dividing his time between Virginia and New York. That year solo shows of his work took place at the Galerie Cahiers d'Art in Paris and the Valentine Gallery in New York. The artist traveled to Paris in 1938 on the occasion of his solo exhibition at the Galerie Pierre, and he became a friend of Paul Eluard, Matta, and Yves Tanguy. In 1939, he began integrating figurative elements into his work. This return to figuration was the hallmark of his postwar paintings. \n", "artistBirthPlace": "Couterne", "artistBirthDate": "1904", "artistDeathDate": "1987"}}, "181": {"paintingDate": "2013", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/2014.27_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on canvas", "paintingName": "Summer Summit", "paintingNo": 186, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "New York", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Hans Hofmann", "artistBirthCountry": "Bavaria", "biography": "Hans Hofmann was born on March 21, 1880, in Wei\u00dfenburg, Bavaria. He was raised in Munich, where in 1898 he began to study at various art schools. The patronage of Philip Freudenberg, a Berlin art collector, enabled Hofmann to live in Paris from 1904 to 1914. There he attended the Acad\u00e9mie Colarossi and the Acad\u00e9mie de la grande chaumi\u00e8re; he met Georges Braque, Pablo Picasso, and other Cubists and was a friend of Robert Delaunay, who stimulated his interest in color. In 1909, Hofmann exhibited with the Sezession (Secession, 1898\u20131932) in Berlin, and in 1910 was given his first solo exhibition at the Galerie Paul Cassirer, Berlin. During this period, he painted in a Cubist style.\nAt the outbreak of World War I, Hofmann was in Munich; disqualified from military service due to a lung condition, he remained in the city and in 1915 opened an art school, which became highly successful. The artist taught at the University of California, Berkeley, during the summer of 1930. He returned to teach in California in 1931, and his first U.S. exhibition took place that summer at the California Palace of the Legion of Honor, San Francisco. In 1932, he closed his Munich school and settled in the United States, later becoming a citizen in 1941. In 1933, he opened his first school in New York, which in 1934 was succeeded by the Hans Hofmann School of Fine Arts; in 1935, he established a summer school in Provincetown, Massachusetts.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Weissenburg", "artistBirthDate": "1880", "artistDeathDate": "1966"}}, "187": {"paintingDate": "2006\u201307", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/2008.24_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Colored pencil and acrylic on canvas", "paintingName": "Presence", "paintingNo": 187, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Shirazeh Houshiary", "artistBirthCountry": "Iran", "biography": "Shirazeh Houshiary was born in 1955 in Shiraz, Iran. After moving to Britain in 1974, she studied at London\u2019s Chelsea School of Art (now Chelsea College of Art and Design, 1976\u201379) and was a Junior Fellow at Cardiff College of Art, Wales (1979\u201380). Houshiary emerged with the New British Sculpture movement artists in the 1980s, alongside Tony Cragg, Richard Deacon, and Anish Kapoor. Though initially working in sculpture, in 1992 she transitioned to making two-dimensional works on canvas as she shifted away from working with defined form in an effort to capture the intangible and formless. \nHoushiary\u2019s three-dimensional works implement Islamic decorative motifs and maintain a minimalist geometry. As part of her project to create a spiritual embodiment of the breath, which she considers to be the fundamental essence of human existence, her move to two-dimensional work marked a further plunge into the elimination of structure. Works such as Touch (1999) and Presence (2006\u201307) comprise amassed marks on a white or black acrylic ground. Drawn from Sufi doctrine and the work of the 13th-century Persian mystic poet Rumi, sacred words are written in Arabic script, minutely repeated and deliberately rendered unintelligible and abstract to produce intricate patterns in graphite and pigment. Houshiary\u2019s consistent use of the white or black field represents a preoccupation with the infinite; while white expresses the absence of boundary, black collapses into itself as with the experience of falling infinitely. Houshiary\u2019s use of word and text is a common denominator within her oeuvre, though their representation constantly evolves. Breath (2003), Houshiary\u2019s first video project, involves a four-screen digital animation with each monitor presenting an expanding and contrasting mist as cultural and religious invocations are recited. The mist is a visualization of the breath, while the soundtrack of Buddhist liturgical music and quotations from the 12th-century German nun Hildegard von Bingen unify into an abstract meditation. Here, the word acts as the formal manifestation of breath, as if misting the screen in an asymmetric, rhythmic movement that is undeniably respiratory in nature. Breath presents the stripped-down representation of an existence that is neither named nor categorized, but simply human.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Shiraz", "artistBirthDate": "1955", "artistDeathDate": ""}}, "184": {"paintingDate": "1940", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/92.4044_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "1940", "paintingName": "Untitled", "paintingNo": 184, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "New York", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Hans Hofmann", "artistBirthCountry": "Bavaria", "biography": "Hans Hofmann was born on March 21, 1880, in Wei\u00dfenburg, Bavaria. He was raised in Munich, where in 1898 he began to study at various art schools. The patronage of Philip Freudenberg, a Berlin art collector, enabled Hofmann to live in Paris from 1904 to 1914. There he attended the Acad\u00e9mie Colarossi and the Acad\u00e9mie de la grande chaumi\u00e8re; he met Georges Braque, Pablo Picasso, and other Cubists and was a friend of Robert Delaunay, who stimulated his interest in color. In 1909, Hofmann exhibited with the Sezession (Secession, 1898\u20131932) in Berlin, and in 1910 was given his first solo exhibition at the Galerie Paul Cassirer, Berlin. During this period, he painted in a Cubist style.\nAt the outbreak of World War I, Hofmann was in Munich; disqualified from military service due to a lung condition, he remained in the city and in 1915 opened an art school, which became highly successful. The artist taught at the University of California, Berkeley, during the summer of 1930. He returned to teach in California in 1931, and his first U.S. exhibition took place that summer at the California Palace of the Legion of Honor, San Francisco. In 1932, he closed his Munich school and settled in the United States, later becoming a citizen in 1941. In 1933, he opened his first school in New York, which in 1934 was succeeded by the Hans Hofmann School of Fine Arts; in 1935, he established a summer school in Provincetown, Massachusetts.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Weissenburg", "artistBirthDate": "1880", "artistDeathDate": "1966"}}, "185": {"paintingDate": "1959\u201360", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/62.1620_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. He was raised in Munich, where in 1898 he began to study at various art schools. The patronage of Philip Freudenberg, a Berlin art collector, enabled Hofmann to live in Paris from 1904 to 1914. There he attended the Acad\u00e9mie Colarossi and the Acad\u00e9mie de la grande chaumi\u00e8re; he met Georges Braque, Pablo Picasso, and other Cubists and was a friend of Robert Delaunay, who stimulated his interest in color. In 1909, Hofmann exhibited with the Sezession (Secession, 1898\u20131932) in Berlin, and in 1910 was given his first solo exhibition at the Galerie Paul Cassirer, Berlin. During this period, he painted in a Cubist style.\nAt the outbreak of World War I, Hofmann was in Munich; disqualified from military service due to a lung condition, he remained in the city and in 1915 opened an art school, which became highly successful. He visited Paris in fall 1936, where he studied at Fernand L\u00e9ger's Acad\u00e9mie contemporaine. During World WarII, Jorn remained in Denmark, painting canvases that reflect the influence of James Ensor, Vasily Kandinsky, Paul Klee, and Joan Mir\u00f3 and contributing to the magazine Helhesten (Ghost horse, nine issues, 1941\u201344). \nJorn traveled to Swedish Lapland in summer 1946, met Constant (Constant Nieuwenhuys) in Paris that fall, and spent six months in Jerba, Tunisia, in 1947\u201348. His first solo exhibition in Paris took place in 1948 at the Galerie Breteau. At about the same time the group Cobra (1948\u201351), an acronym for Copenhagen, Brussels, Amsterdam, was founded by Karel Appel, Constant, Corneille (Guillaume Cornelis Beverloo), Christian Dotremont, Jorn, and Joseph Noiret. The group's unifying doctrine was the complete freedom of expression with an emphasis on color and brushwork. Jorn edited monographs of the Biblioth\u00e8que Cobra before disassociating himself from the movement.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Vejrum", "artistBirthDate": "1914", "artistDeathDate": "1973"}}, "11": {"paintingDate": "1937", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/48.1172.264_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. From 1905 to 1908, he studied to become a teacher in B\u00fcren and then taught in Westphalian primary schools from 1908 to 1913. After attending the K\u00f6nigliche Kunstschule in Berlin from 1913 to 1915, he was certified as an art teacher. Albers studied art in Essen and Munich before entering the Bauhaus in Weimar in 1920. There, he initially concentrated on glass painting and in 1929, as a journeyman, he reorganized the glass workshop. In 1923, he began to teach the Vorkurs, a basic design course. When the Bauhaus moved to Dessau in 1925, he became a professor. In addition to working in glass and metal, he designed furniture and typography.\nAfter the Bauhaus was forced to close in 1933, Albers emigrated to the United States. That same year, he became head of the art department at the newly established, experimental Black Mountain College, near Asheville, North Carolina. Albers continued to teach at Black Mountain until 1949. In 1935, he took the first of many trips to Mexico, and in 1936 was given his first solo show in New York at J. B. Neumann\u2019s New Art Circle. He became a United States citizen in 1939. In 1949, Albers began his Homage to the Square series.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Bottrop", "artistBirthDate": "1888", "artistDeathDate": "1976"}}, "10": {"paintingDate": "1931", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/91.3878_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil with sand on canvas", "paintingName": "Dolamen", "paintingNo": 62, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "New York City", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "James Brooks", "artistBirthCountry": "Missouri", "biography": "James Brooks was born on October 18, 1906, in Saint Louis, Missouri, and moved with his family to Dallas in 1916. He studied art at Southern Methodist University, Dallas, and, after moving to New York in 1926, took night classes at the Art Students League. Like many other Abstract Expressionists, Brooks painted murals for the Works Progress Administration (WPA) Federal Art Project in the late 1930s and early 1940s. His best-known project was a mural titled Flight (1940\u201342) at the International Marine Terminal building at LaGuardia Airport. This vibrant, monumental work\u2014the largest of the WPA murals\u2014measures 12 feet high and 237 feet long and depicts the history of flying, from early mythology to the latest innovations, in a clean, Social Realist style. \nFrom 1942 to 1945, Brooks served as a combat artist with the U.S. Army in the Middle East and returned to New York in 1946, at the height of what would later be termed the Abstract Expressionist movement. An inveterate risk taker, he soon abandoned figuration for abstraction. He reconnected with Jackson Pollock, a friend from the WPA days. Brooks not only took over their Eighth Street studio when Pollock and his wife, artist Lee Krasner, moved to Long Island, but also credited Pollock with encouraging him to try a more gestural style. \nDuring the late 1940s, Brooks's aesthetic evolved from a loose derivation of Cubism to a  moodier, more atmospheric style. In the summer of 1947, Brooks had a breakthrough. He was painting on paper, and glued the paper onto heavy cloth for archival purposes. He noticed that the paste he used to attach the paper to the cloth bled through to the side he was painting on. From then on he would start by working on the cloth and then switch to the front of the painting, combining accidents with deliberate choices in an approach that he used for several years. In the 1960s, Brooks shifted styles again, building compositions out of larger, bolder, and simpler forms.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "St. Louis", "artistBirthDate": "1906", "artistDeathDate": "1992"}}, "63": {"paintingDate": "1999\u20132000", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/2000.66_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on linen", "paintingName": "Puttin' on the Ritz", "paintingNo": 63, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Cecily Brown", "artistBirthCountry": "", "biography": "Born in London in 1969, Cecily Brown attended the Slade School of Fine Art, London, and was as an exchange student at the New York Studio School before receiving a BFA in painting in 1993. A year later she relocated to New York, distancing herself from a London art scene dominated by the new media\u2013oriented Young British Artists. Influenced by Analytic Cubism and Abstract Expressionism as well as academic painting, Brown explores the material and sensual possibilities of oil paint. In exploring issues of sexuality in painting from a feminine perspective, her work often amplifies the eroticism frequently noted in modernist painting, especially Abstract Expressionism, and satirizes the notions of virility often attributed to such work. \nEarly in her career, Brown experimented with other media, most notably animation. Soon after her return to New York, she created the short mixed-media animated film Four Letter Heaven, which premiered at the 1995 Telluride Film Festival. With its humor, sexual imagery, and energetic brushwork, the film introduced themes that would prove prominent in Brown\u2019s later work. The artist soon returned to painting with a series of orgiastic, exuberantly expressionistic images of bunnies. Cartoonish figures and a colorful palette add an element of black comedy to the bacchanalian subject matter, whose imagery recalls both old-master painting and contemporary pornography. In the late 1990s, Brown shifted focus to the human figure and delved deeper into abstraction. In her work from this period, such as On the Town (1998) and The Pyjama Game (1998), bodies and body parts emerge from frenzied brushwork and dissolve into one another. The paintings\u2019 overall eroticism is emphasized by the heavily layered, virtuosic application of paint that draws attention to its sensuous materiality and the pleasure that can be had from looking at art\u2014and at bodies. Placing the viewer at a slight remove from the reality of the paint, their slick, varnished surfaces both highlight the works\u2019 artifice and underscore the voyeurism inherent in viewing. The densely layered brushwork and fragmented imagery overstimulate while signaling Brown\u2019s interest in spectacle. The titles, which are drawn from Hollywood musicals, evoke the pop-cultural predilection for opulent visuals. Brown\u2019s more recent work continues to explore sensuality and spectacle, but in a more sublimated and abstract way. Paintings such as Tender is the Night (1999) or Skulldiver IV (2006\u201307), with only hints of limbs and faces emerging from the tangle of brushstrokes, examine the tension between abstraction and figuration while others, such as The Green, Green Grass of Home (2010), approach complete abstraction. \n", "artistBirthPlace": "London", "artistBirthDate": "1969", "artistDeathDate": ""}}, "322": {"paintingDate": "1964", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/2012.78_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on canvas", "paintingName": "Woman in Evening Dress", "paintingNo": 320, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Paris", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "\u00c9douard Manet", "artistBirthCountry": "", "biography": "Edouard Manet was born on January 23, 1832, in Paris. While studying with Thomas Couture from 1850 to 1856, he drew at the Acad\u00e9mie Suisse and copied the old masters at the Mus\u00e9e du Louvre. After he left Couture\u2019s studio, Manet traveled extensively in Europe, visiting Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany, Austria, and Italy. In 1859 he was rejected by the official Paris Salon, although Eug\u00e8ne Delacroix intervened on his behalf. In 1861 Manet\u2019s paintings were accepted by the Salon and received favorable press, and he began exhibiting at the Galerie Martinet in Paris. During the early 1860s his friendships with Charles Baudelaire and Edgar Degas began. The three paintings Manet sent to the Salon of 1863, including Le D\u00e9jeuner sur l\u2019herbe, were relegated to the Salon des Refus\u00e9s, where they attracted the attention of the critic Th\u00e9ophile Thor\u00e9.\nIn 1865 Manet\u2019s Olympia and Christ Mocked were greeted with great hostility when shown at the Salon. That year the painter traveled to Spain, where he met Th\u00e9odore Duret. He became a friend of Emile Zola in 1866, when the writer defended him in a controversial article for the periodical L\u2019Ev\u00e8nement. In 1867 Zola published a longer article on Manet, who that year exhibited his work in an independent pavilion at the Paris World\u2019s Fair. The artist spent the first of several summers in Boulogne at this time. In 1868 two of his works were accepted by the Salon but were not shown to advantage.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Paris", "artistBirthDate": "1832", "artistDeathDate": "1883"}}, "321": {"paintingDate": "1880", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/91.3909_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil and pebbles on canvas", "paintingName": "Sassetti", "paintingNo": 326, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Milan", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Piero Manzoni", "artistBirthCountry": "Italy", "biography": "Piero Manzoni was born Count Meroni Manzoni di Chiosca e Poggiolo on July 13, 1933, in Soncino, Italy. Self-taught, he started his artistic career as a painter, making gestural, abstract works. In the 1950s, he began to question traditional methods of art making and explored the ties among artistic practice, the collective unconscious, and so-called primal, universal imagery through manifestos: one coproduced with Ettore Sordini, Camillo Corvi-Morra, and Giuseppe Zecca (1956) and one produced independently (1957). Both were titled \"Per la scoperta di una zona di immagini\" (For the discovery of a zone of images). Shortly afterward and influenced by his visit to Yves Klein's exhibition at the Galleria Apollinaire, Milan, Proposte monochrome, epoca blu (Monochrome propositions, blue period, 1957)\u2014a display of 11 virtually identical monochrome blue paintings\u2014he began the Achrome series (1957\u201363). In direct response to Klein's paintings, Manzoni experimented with a series of works in varying materials, all lacking color. He began with a series of gesso-coated canvases, moving on to canvas covered in kaolin, a form of white clay, which he then cut or folded. Later, he produced Achromes of other colorless materials: white cotton wool, fiberglass, rabbit skin, and bread, even experimenting with phosphorescent paint so that the \"colors\" would change over time.\nManzoni began to interrogate the nature of the art object itself with a series of proto-Conceptual works. In 1958, he created the first version of Line 1000 Meters Long, a metal drum containing a roll of paper with a precisely measured ink line along its length. In the same year, he began to produce do-it-yourself pneumatic sculptures, comprising a balloon and tripod packed in a wooden case; the buyer could either inflate the balloon on one's own or have Manzoni perform the task for a fee. From 1959 to 1960, Manzoni and artist Enrico Castellani published the only two issues of their journal, Azimuth. In 1961 at the Galleria La Tartaruga, Rome, Manzoni began signing his name on models as well as gallery visitors, issuing them with a stamped certificate and declaring this body of work Sculture viventi (living sculptures); that same year he created Merda d'artista, an edition of 90 30-gram cans, ostensibly containing the artist's excrement, each valued at the market price of gold. His works were often featured at Galleria Azimut, the gallery that he founded with Castellani and was open from 1959 to 1960. For the final exhibition, Manzoni distributed hard-boiled eggs marked with his thumbprint to the audience (Consumption of Art by the Art-Devouring Public, 1960), ironically positioning art in an ecclesiastical context of consumption and resurrection. He spent the final years of his life continuing to produce Achromes, experimenting with new materials including chemically altered cotton (which changed color with fluctuations in temperature), kaolin-covered dinner rolls, rocks, and wastepaper. Manzoni died of heart attack in his studio on February 6, 1963, in Milan.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Soncino", "artistBirthDate": "1933", "artistDeathDate": "1963"}}, "327": {"paintingDate": "1962", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/2012.79_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Self-taught, he started his artistic career as a painter, making gestural, abstract works. In the 1950s, he began to question traditional methods of art making and explored the ties among artistic practice, the collective unconscious, and so-called primal, universal imagery through manifestos: one coproduced with Ettore Sordini, Camillo Corvi-Morra, and Giuseppe Zecca (1956) and one produced independently (1957). Both were titled \"Per la scoperta di una zona di immagini\" (For the discovery of a zone of images). Shortly afterward and influenced by his visit to Yves Klein's exhibition at the Galleria Apollinaire, Milan, Proposte monochrome, epoca blu (Monochrome propositions, blue period, 1957)\u2014a display of 11 virtually identical monochrome blue paintings\u2014he began the Achrome series (1957\u201363). In direct response to Klein's paintings, Manzoni experimented with a series of works in varying materials, all lacking color. He began with a series of gesso-coated canvases, moving on to canvas covered in kaolin, a form of white clay, which he then cut or folded. Later, he produced Achromes of other colorless materials: white cotton wool, fiberglass, rabbit skin, and bread, even experimenting with phosphorescent paint so that the \"colors\" would change over time.\nManzoni began to interrogate the nature of the art object itself with a series of proto-Conceptual works. In 1958, he created the first version of Line 1000 Meters Long, a metal drum containing a roll of paper with a precisely measured ink line along its length. In the same year, he began to produce do-it-yourself pneumatic sculptures, comprising a balloon and tripod packed in a wooden case; the buyer could either inflate the balloon on one's own or have Manzoni perform the task for a fee. From 1959 to 1960, Manzoni and artist Enrico Castellani published the only two issues of their journal, Azimuth. In 1961 at the Galleria La Tartaruga, Rome, Manzoni began signing his name on models as well as gallery visitors, issuing them with a stamped certificate and declaring this body of work Sculture viventi (living sculptures); that same year he created Merda d'artista, an edition of 90 30-gram cans, ostensibly containing the artist's excrement, each valued at the market price of gold. His works were often featured at Galleria Azimut, the gallery that he founded with Castellani and was open from 1959 to 1960. For the final exhibition, Manzoni distributed hard-boiled eggs marked with his thumbprint to the audience (Consumption of Art by the Art-Devouring Public, 1960), ironically positioning art in an ecclesiastical context of consumption and resurrection. He spent the final years of his life continuing to produce Achromes, experimenting with new materials including chemically altered cotton (which changed color with fluctuations in temperature), kaolin-covered dinner rolls, rocks, and wastepaper. The son of a landscape painter, he decided to become an artist after a year of military service interrupted his plans to study philology. From 1900 to 1902 he studied at the Kunstakademie in Munich with Gabriel Hackl and Wilhelm von Diez. The following year, during a visit to France, he was introduced to Japanese woodcuts and the work of the Impressionists in Paris.\nMarc suffered from severe depression from 1904 to 1907. In 1907 he went again to Paris, where he responded enthusiastically to the work of Paul Gauguin, Vincent van Gogh, the Cubists, and the Expressionists; later, he was impressed by the Henri Matisse exhibition in Munich in 1910. During this period he received steady income from the animal-anatomy lessons he gave to artists.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Munich", "artistBirthDate": "1880", "artistDeathDate": "1916"}}, "329": {"paintingDate": "1911", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/49.1210_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. The son of a landscape painter, he decided to become an artist after a year of military service interrupted his plans to study philology. From 1900 to 1902 he studied at the Kunstakademie in Munich with Gabriel Hackl and Wilhelm von Diez. The following year, during a visit to France, he was introduced to Japanese woodcuts and the work of the Impressionists in Paris.\nMarc suffered from severe depression from 1904 to 1907. In 1907 he went again to Paris, where he responded enthusiastically to the work of Paul Gauguin, Vincent van Gogh, the Cubists, and the Expressionists; later, he was impressed by the Henri Matisse exhibition in Munich in 1910. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on canvas", "paintingName": "Sketch for \"Composition II\"", "paintingNo": 201, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Neuilly-sur-Seine", "artistDeathCountry": "France", "artistName": "Vasily Kandinsky", "artistBirthCountry": "", "biography": "Vasily Kandinsky was born on December 4, 1866, in Moscow. From 1886 through 1892 he studied law and economics at the University of Moscow, where he lectured after graduation. In 1896 he declined a teaching position in order to study art in Munich with Anton Azbe from 1897 to 1899 and at the Kunstakademie with Franz von Stuck in 1900. Kandinsky taught in 1901\u201303 at the art school of the Phalanx, a group he cofounded in Munich. One of his students, Gabriele M\u00fcnter, would be his companion until 1914. In 1902 Kandinsky exhibited for the first time with the Berlin Secession and produced his first woodcuts. In 1903 and 1904 he began his travels in Italy, the Netherlands, and North Africa and his visits to Russia. He showed at the Salon d\u2019Automne in Paris from 1904.\nIn 1909 Kandinsky was elected president of the newly founded Neue K\u00fcnstlervereinigung M\u00fcnchen (NKVM). The group\u2019s first show took place at Heinrich Thannhauser\u2019s Moderne Galerie in Munich in 1909. In 1911 Kandinsky and Franz Marc began to make plans for Der Blaue Reiter Almanac, although the publication would not appear until the following year. Kandinsky\u2019s On the Spiritual in Art was published in December 1911. He and Marc withdrew from the NKVM in that month, and shortly thereafter the Blaue Reiter group\u2019s first exhibition was held at the Moderne Galerie. In 1912 the second Blaue Reiter show was held at the Galerie Hans Goltz, Munich. Kandinsky\u2019s first solo show was held at Der Sturm gallery in Berlin in 1912. In 1913 one of his works was included in the Armory Show in New York and the Erste deutsche Herbstsalon at the Der Sturm gallery in Berlin. Kandinsky lived in Russia from 1914 to 1921, principally in Moscow, where he held a position at the People\u2019s Commissariat of Education.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Moscow", "artistBirthDate": "1866", "artistDeathDate": "1944"}}, "200": {"paintingDate": "1909", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/50.1295_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. From 1886 through 1892 he studied law and economics at the University of Moscow, where he lectured after graduation. In 1896 he declined a teaching position in order to study art in Munich with Anton Azbe from 1897 to 1899 and at the Kunstakademie with Franz von Stuck in 1900. Kandinsky taught in 1901\u201303 at the art school of the Phalanx, a group he cofounded in Munich. One of his students, Gabriele M\u00fcnter, would be his companion until 1914. The group\u2019s first show took place at Heinrich Thannhauser\u2019s Moderne Galerie in Munich in 1909. In 1911 Kandinsky and Franz Marc began to make plans for Der Blaue Reiter Almanac, although the publication would not appear until the following year. Kandinsky\u2019s On the Spiritual in Art was published in December 1911. He and Marc withdrew from the NKVM in that month, and shortly thereafter the Blaue Reiter group\u2019s first exhibition was held at the Moderne Galerie. In 1912 the second Blaue Reiter show was held at the Galerie Hans Goltz, Munich. Kandinsky\u2019s first solo show was held at Der Sturm gallery in Berlin in 1912. In 1913 one of his works was included in the Armory Show in New York and the Erste deutsche Herbstsalon at the Der Sturm gallery in Berlin. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on board", "paintingName": "Landscape with Rolling Hills", "paintingNo": 203, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Neuilly-sur-Seine", "artistDeathCountry": "France", "artistName": "Vasily Kandinsky", "artistBirthCountry": "", "biography": "Vasily Kandinsky was born on December 4, 1866, in Moscow. From 1886 through 1892 he studied law and economics at the University of Moscow, where he lectured after graduation. In 1896 he declined a teaching position in order to study art in Munich with Anton Azbe from 1897 to 1899 and at the Kunstakademie with Franz von Stuck in 1900. Kandinsky taught in 1901\u201303 at the art school of the Phalanx, a group he cofounded in Munich. One of his students, Gabriele M\u00fcnter, would be his companion until 1914. In 1902 Kandinsky exhibited for the first time with the Berlin Secession and produced his first woodcuts. In 1903 and 1904 he began his travels in Italy, the Netherlands, and North Africa and his visits to Russia. He showed at the Salon d\u2019Automne in Paris from 1904.\nIn 1909 Kandinsky was elected president of the newly founded Neue K\u00fcnstlervereinigung M\u00fcnchen (NKVM). The group\u2019s first show took place at Heinrich Thannhauser\u2019s Moderne Galerie in Munich in 1909. In 1911 Kandinsky and Franz Marc began to make plans for Der Blaue Reiter Almanac, although the publication would not appear until the following year. Kandinsky\u2019s On the Spiritual in Art was published in December 1911. He and Marc withdrew from the NKVM in that month, and shortly thereafter the Blaue Reiter group\u2019s first exhibition was held at the Moderne Galerie. In 1912 the second Blaue Reiter show was held at the Galerie Hans Goltz, Munich. Kandinsky\u2019s first solo show was held at Der Sturm gallery in Berlin in 1912. In 1913 one of his works was included in the Armory Show in New York and the Erste deutsche Herbstsalon at the Der Sturm gallery in Berlin. Kandinsky lived in Russia from 1914 to 1921, principally in Moscow, where he held a position at the People\u2019s Commissariat of Education.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Moscow", "artistBirthDate": "1866", "artistDeathDate": "1944"}}, "202": {"paintingDate": "1910", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/41.504_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. From 1886 through 1892 he studied law and economics at the University of Moscow, where he lectured after graduation. In 1896 he declined a teaching position in order to study art in Munich with Anton Azbe from 1897 to 1899 and at the Kunstakademie with Franz von Stuck in 1900. Kandinsky taught in 1901\u201303 at the art school of the Phalanx, a group he cofounded in Munich. One of his students, Gabriele M\u00fcnter, would be his companion until 1914. In 1902 Kandinsky exhibited for the first time with the Berlin Secession and produced his first woodcuts. In 1903 and 1904 he began his travels in Italy, the Netherlands, and North Africa and his visits to Russia. He showed at the Salon d\u2019Automne in Paris from 1904.\nIn 1909 Kandinsky was elected president of the newly founded Neue K\u00fcnstlervereinigung M\u00fcnchen (NKVM). The group\u2019s first show took place at Heinrich Thannhauser\u2019s Moderne Galerie in Munich in 1909. In 1911 Kandinsky and Franz Marc began to make plans for Der Blaue Reiter Almanac, although the publication would not appear until the following year. Kandinsky\u2019s On the Spiritual in Art was published in December 1911. He and Marc withdrew from the NKVM in that month, and shortly thereafter the Blaue Reiter group\u2019s first exhibition was held at the Moderne Galerie. In 1912 the second Blaue Reiter show was held at the Galerie Hans Goltz, Munich. Kandinsky\u2019s first solo show was held at Der Sturm gallery in Berlin in 1912. In 1913 one of his works was included in the Armory Show in New York and the Erste deutsche Herbstsalon at the Der Sturm gallery in Berlin. From 1907 to 1910 he studied in Saint Petersburg, at the Imperial Society for the Protection of the Arts, and later with L\u00e9on Bakst. In 1910 he moved to Paris, where he associated with Guillaume Apollinaire and Robert Delaunay and encountered Fauvism and Cubism. He participated in the Salon des Ind\u00e9pendants and the Salon d\u2019Automne in 1912. His first solo show was held in 1914 at Der Sturm gallery in Berlin.\nChagall visited Russia in 1914 and was prevented from returning to Paris by the outbreak of war. He settled in Vitebsk, where he was appointed Commissar for Art in 1918. He founded the Vitebsk Popular Art School and directed it until disagreements with the Suprematists resulted in his resignation in 1920. He moved to Moscow and executed his first stage designs for the State Jewish Chamber Theater there. After a sojourn in Berlin, Chagall returned to Paris in 1923 and met Ambroise Vollard. His first retrospective took place in 1924 at the Galerie Barbazanges-Hodebert, Paris. During the 1930s he traveled to Palestine, the Netherlands, Spain, Poland, and Italy. In 1933 the Kunsthalle Basel held a major retrospective of his work.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Vitebsk", "artistBirthDate": "1887", "artistDeathDate": "1985"}}, "76": {"paintingDate": "1899", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/54.1387_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "1899", "paintingName": "Man with Crossed Arms", "paintingNo": 76, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Aix-en-Provence", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Paul C\u00e9zanne", "artistBirthCountry": "France", "biography": "Paul C\u00e9zanne was born on January 19, 1839, in Aix-en-Provence, France. While in school, he enrolled in the free-drawing academy in Aix, which he attended intermittently for several years. In 1858 he graduated from the Coll\u00e8ge Bourbon, where he had become an intimate friend of fellow student Emile Zola. C\u00e9zanne entered the law school of the University of Aix in 1859 to placate his father but abandoned his studies to join Zola in Paris in 1861. For the next twenty years C\u00e9zanne divided his time between the Midi and Paris. While in the capital, he briefly attended the Atelier Suisse with Camille Pissarro, whose art later came to influence his own. In 1862 C\u00e9zanne began long friendships with Claude Monet and Pierre-Auguste Renoir. His paintings were included in the 1863 Salon des Refus\u00e9s, which displayed works not accepted by the jury of the official Paris Salon. The Salon itself rejected C\u00e9zanne\u2019s submissions each year from 1864 to 1869.\nFollowing the declaration of the Franco-Prussian War in 1870, C\u00e9zanne left Paris for Aix-en-Provence and then nearby L\u2019Estaque, where he continued to paint. He made the first of several visits to Pontoise in 1872; there, he worked alongside Pissarro. He participated in the first Impressionist exhibition of 1874. From 1876 to 1879 his works were again rejected by the Salon. C\u00e9zanne showed again with the Impressionists in 1877 in their third exhibition. At that time, Georges Rivi\u00e8re was one of the few critics to support his art. In 1882 the Salon accepted his work for the first and only time. Beginning in 1883 C\u00e9zanne resided in the South of France, returning to Paris occasionally.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Aix-en-Provence", "artistBirthDate": "1839", "artistDeathDate": "1906"}}, "75": {"paintingDate": "1894\u201395", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/78.2514.6_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. While in school, he enrolled in the free-drawing academy in Aix, which he attended intermittently for several years. In 1858 he graduated from the Coll\u00e8ge Bourbon, where he had become an intimate friend of fellow student Emile Zola. C\u00e9zanne entered the law school of the University of Aix in 1859 to placate his father but abandoned his studies to join Zola in Paris in 1861. For the next twenty years C\u00e9zanne divided his time between the Midi and Paris. While in the capital, he briefly attended the Atelier Suisse with Camille Pissarro, whose art later came to influence his own. In 1862 C\u00e9zanne began long friendships with Claude Monet and Pierre-Auguste Renoir. His paintings were included in the 1863 Salon des Refus\u00e9s, which displayed works not accepted by the jury of the official Paris Salon. The Salon itself rejected C\u00e9zanne\u2019s submissions each year from 1864 to 1869.\nFollowing the declaration of the Franco-Prussian War in 1870, C\u00e9zanne left Paris for Aix-en-Provence and then nearby L\u2019Estaque, where he continued to paint. He made the first of several visits to Pontoise in 1872; there, he worked alongside Pissarro. He participated in the first Impressionist exhibition of 1874. From 1876 to 1879 his works were again rejected by the Salon. C\u00e9zanne showed again with the Impressionists in 1877 in their third exhibition. At that time, Georges Rivi\u00e8re was one of the few critics to support his art. In 1882 the Salon accepted his work for the first and only time. Beginning in 1883 C\u00e9zanne resided in the South of France, returning to Paris occasionally.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Aix-en-Provence", "artistBirthDate": "1839", "artistDeathDate": "1906"}}, "74": {"paintingDate": "1885\u201387", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/91.3907_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. In 1858 he graduated from the Coll\u00e8ge Bourbon, where he had become an intimate friend of fellow student Emile Zola. C\u00e9zanne entered the law school of the University of Aix in 1859 to placate his father but abandoned his studies to join Zola in Paris in 1861. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on canvas", "paintingName": "Madame C\u00e9zanne", "paintingNo": 73, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Aix-en-Provence", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Paul C\u00e9zanne", "artistBirthCountry": "France", "biography": "Paul C\u00e9zanne was born on January 19, 1839, in Aix-en-Provence, France. While in school, he enrolled in the free-drawing academy in Aix, which he attended intermittently for several years. In 1858 he graduated from the Coll\u00e8ge Bourbon, where he had become an intimate friend of fellow student Emile Zola. C\u00e9zanne entered the law school of the University of Aix in 1859 to placate his father but abandoned his studies to join Zola in Paris in 1861. For the next twenty years C\u00e9zanne divided his time between the Midi and Paris. While in the capital, he briefly attended the Atelier Suisse with Camille Pissarro, whose art later came to influence his own. In 1862 C\u00e9zanne began long friendships with Claude Monet and Pierre-Auguste Renoir. His paintings were included in the 1863 Salon des Refus\u00e9s, which displayed works not accepted by the jury of the official Paris Salon. The Salon itself rejected C\u00e9zanne\u2019s submissions each year from 1864 to 1869.\nFollowing the declaration of the Franco-Prussian War in 1870, C\u00e9zanne left Paris for Aix-en-Provence and then nearby L\u2019Estaque, where he continued to paint. He made the first of several visits to Pontoise in 1872; there, he worked alongside Pissarro. He participated in the first Impressionist exhibition of 1874. From 1876 to 1879 his works were again rejected by the Salon. C\u00e9zanne showed again with the Impressionists in 1877 in their third exhibition. At that time, Georges Rivi\u00e8re was one of the few critics to support his art. In 1882 the Salon accepted his work for the first and only time. Beginning in 1883 C\u00e9zanne resided in the South of France, returning to Paris occasionally.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Aix-en-Provence", "artistBirthDate": "1839", "artistDeathDate": "1906"}}, "72": {"paintingDate": "1879\u201380", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/78.2514.4_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. While in school, he enrolled in the free-drawing academy in Aix, which he attended intermittently for several years. In 1858 he graduated from the Coll\u00e8ge Bourbon, where he had become an intimate friend of fellow student Emile Zola. C\u00e9zanne entered the law school of the University of Aix in 1859 to placate his father but abandoned his studies to join Zola in Paris in 1861. For the next twenty years C\u00e9zanne divided his time between the Midi and Paris. While in the capital, he briefly attended the Atelier Suisse with Camille Pissarro, whose art later came to influence his own. In 1862 C\u00e9zanne began long friendships with Claude Monet and Pierre-Auguste Renoir. His paintings were included in the 1863 Salon des Refus\u00e9s, which displayed works not accepted by the jury of the official Paris Salon. The Salon itself rejected C\u00e9zanne\u2019s submissions each year from 1864 to 1869.\nFollowing the declaration of the Franco-Prussian War in 1870, C\u00e9zanne left Paris for Aix-en-Provence and then nearby L\u2019Estaque, where he continued to paint. He made the first of several visits to Pontoise in 1872; there, he worked alongside Pissarro. He participated in the first Impressionist exhibition of 1874. From 1876 to 1879 his works were again rejected by the Salon. C\u00e9zanne showed again with the Impressionists in 1877 in their third exhibition. At that time, Georges Rivi\u00e8re was one of the few critics to support his art. In 1882 the Salon accepted his work for the first and only time. From 1907 to 1910 he studied in Saint Petersburg, at the Imperial Society for the Protection of the Arts, and later with L\u00e9on Bakst. In 1910 he moved to Paris, where he associated with Guillaume Apollinaire and Robert Delaunay and encountered Fauvism and Cubism. He participated in the Salon des Ind\u00e9pendants and the Salon d\u2019Automne in 1912. His first solo show was held in 1914 at Der Sturm gallery in Berlin.\nChagall visited Russia in 1914 and was prevented from returning to Paris by the outbreak of war. He settled in Vitebsk, where he was appointed Commissar for Art in 1918. He founded the Vitebsk Popular Art School and directed it until disagreements with the Suprematists resulted in his resignation in 1920. He moved to Moscow and executed his first stage designs for the State Jewish Chamber Theater there. After a sojourn in Berlin, Chagall returned to Paris in 1923 and met Ambroise Vollard. His first retrospective took place in 1924 at the Galerie Barbazanges-Hodebert, Paris. During the 1930s he traveled to Palestine, the Netherlands, Spain, Poland, and Italy. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "late 1960s", "paintingName": "Untitled", "paintingNo": 2, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Rome", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Carla Accardi", "artistBirthCountry": "Italy", "biography": "Born on October 9, 1924, in Trapani, Italy, Carla Accardi trained as a painter at the Accademia di belle arti, Florence, before moving to Rome in 1946. Accardi quickly became part of the inner circle of the Art Club and was a frequent visitor to Pietro Consagra's studio. There she met the artists with whom she would establish the influential postwar group Forma 1 (Form 1, 1947\u201351): Consagra, Piero Dorazio, Mino Guerrini, Achille Perilli, Antonio Sanfilippo (whom she would marry), and Giulio Turcato. The group\u2019s manifesto, which Accardi signed in 1947, called for reconciling Marxist politics with abstract art. The group\u2019s first exhibition occurred in Rome in 1947, and Accardi's first solo show soon followed, in 1950 at the Galleria Age d\u2019or, Rome. Her early paintings consisted of interlocking geometric forms. \n In the 1950s, Accardi was involved in the wide-reaching attempts to revolutionize abstraction through the hybridization of geometric abstraction and gestural painting, both in Italy, where she appeared in Arte astratta e concreta in Italia\u20141951 (Abstract and concrete art in Italy\u20141951) at the Galleria nazionale d\u2019arte moderna, Rome, and in France, where art critic Michel Tapi\u00e9 took an interest in her work. (Tapi\u00e9 would later write the introduction to the catalogue accompanying Accardi's 1959 solo exhibition at the Galleria Notizie in Turin.) After forswearing painting from 1952 to 1953, Accardi began to introduce pseudo-calligraphic signs into abstract images, as in Labirinto a settori (Labyrinths and fields, 1957), while reducing her palette to white-on-black compositions to explore the relationship between figure and ground. \nIn 1961 Accardi reintegrated color and began painting on sicofoil, a transparent plastic, instead of canvas. She showcased these new strategies at the 1964 Venice Biennale. By the mid-1960s, she was using these new materials sculpturally. Tenda (Tent, 1965) and Triplice Tenda (Triple tent, 1969) feature sheets of plastic assembled into a tent and covered with brightly colored brushstroke patterns. This phase of Accardi's oeuvre, which was celebrated in the Ambiente/Arte section of the 1976 Venice Biennale, would prove influential for Arte Povera. In the 1980s she returned to canvas and shifted her focus to the use of signs and chromatic juxtapositions.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Trapani", "artistBirthDate": "1924", "artistDeathDate": "2014"}}, "542": {"paintingDate": "1961", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/2012.98_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. From 1948 to 1951, he studied at the School of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston; Washington and Lee University, Lexington; and Art Students League, New York, where he met Robert Rauschenberg. At Rauschenberg\u2019s encouragement, he attended Black Mountain College near Asheville, North Carolina, in 1951 and 1952, where he studied under Franz Kline, Robert Motherwell, and Ben Shahn.\nThe Kootz Gallery, New York, organized his first solo exhibition in 1951. At this time, his work was influenced by Kline\u2019s black-and-white gestural Abstract Expressionism as well as by Paul Klee\u2019s childlike imagery. In 1952, Twombly received a grant from the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, Richmond, that enabled him to travel to North Africa, Spain, Italy, and France. On his return in 1953, he served in the army as a cryptologist. From 1955 to 1959, he worked in New York and Italy, finally settling in Rome. During this period he began to create his first abstract sculptures, which, although varied in shape and material, were always coated with white paint. In Italy, he began to work on a larger scale and distanced himself from his former Expressionist scribbles, moving toward a more literal use of text and numbers, drawing inspiration from poetry, mythology, and classical history. He subsequently created a vocabulary of various signs and marks, sometimes sexually charged, that read metaphorically rather than according to any form of traditional iconography.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Lexington", "artistBirthDate": "1928", "artistDeathDate": "2011"}}, "543": {"paintingDate": "1967", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/2012.97_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. From 1948 to 1951, he studied at the School of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston; Washington and Lee University, Lexington; and Art Students League, New York, where he met Robert Rauschenberg. At Rauschenberg\u2019s encouragement, he attended Black Mountain College near Asheville, North Carolina, in 1951 and 1952, where he studied under Franz Kline, Robert Motherwell, and Ben Shahn.\nThe Kootz Gallery, New York, organized his first solo exhibition in 1951. At this time, his work was influenced by Kline\u2019s black-and-white gestural Abstract Expressionism as well as by Paul Klee\u2019s childlike imagery. In 1952, Twombly received a grant from the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, Richmond, that enabled him to travel to North Africa, Spain, Italy, and France. On his return in 1953, he served in the army as a cryptologist. From 1955 to 1959, he worked in New York and Italy, finally settling in Rome. During this period he began to create his first abstract sculptures, which, although varied in shape and material, were always coated with white paint. In Italy, he began to work on a larger scale and distanced himself from his former Expressionist scribbles, moving toward a more literal use of text and numbers, drawing inspiration from poetry, mythology, and classical history. He subsequently created a vocabulary of various signs and marks, sometimes sexually charged, that read metaphorically rather than according to any form of traditional iconography.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Lexington", "artistBirthDate": "1928", "artistDeathDate": "2011"}}, "540": {"paintingDate": "2000", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/2001.21_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on canvas", "paintingName": "Leopard", "paintingNo": 540, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Luc Tuymans", "artistBirthCountry": "Belgium", "biography": "Born in 1958 in Mortsel, Belgium, Luc Tuymans studied painting in Brussels and Antwerp, Belgium, before earning a degree in art history from the Vrije Universiteit, Brussels (1986). After experimenting with film from 1981 to 1985, Tuymans returned to painting. Modeled from found photographs and media images, his paintings examine moments of individual and collective trauma obliquely by focusing on the unremarkableness of source images that both belie their sinister nature and signal the limits of representation. Influenced by his work in film, he tightly crops his images and subjects them to several layers of mediation, typically rephotographing and drawing them before rendering the final work in oil in a single day. Representations of representations, the resulting blurred, bleached paintings, which Tuymans has dubbed \u201cauthentic forgeries,\u201d draw attention to the distortions and occlusions of historical memory.\u00b9 \nThe Holocaust is an important theme in Tuymans\u2019s early work. In Gas Chamber (1986), the horrific purpose of the bare, windowless room lightly sketched in stained, sepia browns is only revealed through the work\u2019s title. By refusing to dramatize a traumatic chapter in European history, the painting instead emphasizes both the banality of evil and the treacherous nature of representation. Belgian colonialism is another significant subject, and while representing Belgium at the 2001 Venice Biennale, he incited scandal by exhibiting a series of paintings on the 1961 assassination of Congolese prime minister Patrice Lumumba. The works range from representations of iconic images of Lumumba and the Belgian king Baudouin I to those with further layers of mediation. Reconstruction (2000), based on a documentary reenactment of Lumumba\u2019s murder, collapses several layers of representation. The source image is itself a fabrication, a reconstruction of an event that was not photographically documented, and Tuymans\u2019s re-presentation of it as a painting obscures the constructed nature of the source and confuses his work\u2019s relationship to historical reality. In more recent works, Tuymans has explored American culture and politics. For Documenta, Kassel, Germany (2002), and in response to the attacks of September 11, he produced an immense yet characteristically bland still life, highlighting art\u2019s inability to address violence of such magnitude. Later series delve into the dark side of Americana, corporate culture, and the utopianism of Walt Disney.\nCo-organized by the Wexner Center for the Arts, Columbus (2009\u201310), and San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (2010), a retrospective of Tuymans\u2019s work traveled to the Dallas Museum of Art (2010); Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago (2010\u201311); and Palais des beaux-arts, Brussels (2011). A European retrospective appeared at the M\u0171csarnok Kunsthalle, Budapest (2007\u201308); Haus der Kunst, Munich (2008); and Zach\u0119ta Narodowa Galeria Sztuki, Warsaw (2008). His work has appeared in group shows at venues including the Museum of Modern Art, New York (1996, 1997, 2000, 2001, 2004\u201309, 2012); Centre Georges Pompidou, Paris, (1996, 2002); and Mori Art Museum, Tokyo (2006). Tuymans\u2019s work was shown at the Documenta, Kassel, Germany (1992, 2002); Venice Biennale (1997, 2001, 2003); and S\u00e3o Paulo Biennial (2004). Tuymans lives and works in Antwerp.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Mortsel", "artistBirthDate": "1958", "artistDeathDate": ""}}, "541": {"paintingDate": "1960", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/91.3975_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. On his return in 1953, he served in the army as a cryptologist. From 1955 to 1959, he worked in New York and Italy, finally settling in Rome. During this period he began to create his first abstract sculptures, which, although varied in shape and material, were always coated with white paint. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on canvas", "paintingName": "Composition in Gray (Rag-time)", "paintingNo": 546, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Davos", "artistDeathCountry": "Switzerland", "artistName": "Theo van Doesburg", "artistBirthCountry": "Netherlands", "biography": "Christian Emil Marie K\u00fcpper, who adopted the pseudonym Theo van Doesburg, was born in Utrecht, the Netherlands, on August 30, 1883. His first exhibition of paintings was held in 1908 in the Hague. In the early 1910s he wrote poetry and established himself as an art critic. From 1914 to 1916 van Doesburg served in the Dutch army, after which time he settled in Leiden and began his collaboration with the architects J. J. P. Oud and Jan Wils. In 1917 they founded the group De Stijl and the periodical of the same name; other original members were Vilmos Husz\u00e1r, Piet Mondrian, Bart van der Leck, and Georges Vantongerloo. Van Doesburg executed decorations for Oud\u2019s De Vonk project in Noordwijkerhout in 1917.\nIn 1920 he resumed his writing, using the pen name I. K. Bonset and later Aldo Camini. Van Doesburg visited Berlin and Weimar in 1921 and the following year taught at the Weimar Bauhaus, where he associated with Raoul Hausmann, Le Corbusier, Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, and Hans Richter. He was interested in Dada at this time and worked with Kurt Schwitters as well as Jean Arp, Tristan Tzara, and others on the review M\u00e9cano in 1922. Exhibitions of the architectural designs of Gerrit Rietveld, van Doesburg, and Cor van Eesteren were held in Paris in 1923 at L\u00e9once Rosenberg\u2019s Galerie l\u2019Effort Moderne and in 1924 at the Ecole Sp\u00e9ciale d\u2019Architecture.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Utrecht", "artistBirthDate": "1883", "artistDeathDate": "1931"}}, "547": {"paintingDate": "1925\u201326", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/76.2553.41_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on canvas", "paintingName": "Counter-Composition XIII", "paintingNo": 547, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Davos", "artistDeathCountry": "Switzerland", "artistName": "Theo van Doesburg", "artistBirthCountry": "Netherlands", "biography": "Christian Emil Marie K\u00fcpper, who adopted the pseudonym Theo van Doesburg, was born in Utrecht, the Netherlands, on August 30, 1883. His first exhibition of paintings was held in 1908 in the Hague. In the early 1910s he wrote poetry and established himself as an art critic. From 1914 to 1916 van Doesburg served in the Dutch army, after which time he settled in Leiden and began his collaboration with the architects J. J. P. Oud and Jan Wils. In 1917 they founded the group De Stijl and the periodical of the same name; other original members were Vilmos Husz\u00e1r, Piet Mondrian, Bart van der Leck, and Georges Vantongerloo. Van Doesburg executed decorations for Oud\u2019s De Vonk project in Noordwijkerhout in 1917.\nIn 1920 he resumed his writing, using the pen name I. K. Bonset and later Aldo Camini. Van Doesburg visited Berlin and Weimar in 1921 and the following year taught at the Weimar Bauhaus, where he associated with Raoul Hausmann, Le Corbusier, Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, and Hans Richter. He was interested in Dada at this time and worked with Kurt Schwitters as well as Jean Arp, Tristan Tzara, and others on the review M\u00e9cano in 1922. Exhibitions of the architectural designs of Gerrit Rietveld, van Doesburg, and Cor van Eesteren were held in Paris in 1923 at L\u00e9once Rosenberg\u2019s Galerie l\u2019Effort Moderne and in 1924 at the Ecole Sp\u00e9ciale d\u2019Architecture.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Utrecht", "artistBirthDate": "1883", "artistDeathDate": "1931"}}, "544": {"paintingDate": "1959\u201360", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/82.2913_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on canvas", "paintingName": "Red Lode", "paintingNo": 544, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Provincetown", "artistDeathCountry": "Massachusetts", "artistName": "Jack Tworkov", "artistBirthCountry": "Russia (now Poland)", "biography": "Jack Tworkov was born on August 15, 1900, in Bia\u0142a Podlaska, Russia (now Poland). His family immigrated to the United States in 1913. Living in New York\u2019s Lower East Side, Tworkov worked hard to learn English. He attended Columbia University to study literature and become a writer. His sister, meanwhile, became an artist and introduced Tworkov to the New York art scene. She encouraged him to visit the creative community thriving in Provincetown, Massachusetts, a town he would visit throughout his life. Also around this time, Tworkov first saw the work of Paul C\u00e9zanne and Henri Matisse, which inspired him to leave Columbia and pursue a painting career. He studied at the National Academy of Design (1923) and then at the Art Students League (1925\u201326). Along with this formal training, he absorbed the dominant trends in European art and was especially influenced by Vasily Kandinsky, Paul Klee, and Joan Mir\u00f3.\nTworkov\u2019s early work owes much to C\u00e9zanne. Applying paint in large blocks that flaunt the flatness of the picture plane, his paintings cohered into still lifes, landscapes, and narrative scenes. During the Great Depression, Tworkov\u2019s subject matter took on social issues. He was employed in the Works Progress Administration Federal Art Project easel division from 1934 to 1941. After World War II, Tworkov met Willem de Kooning, whose emotive and gestural style inspired him. He became part of the community of emerging Abstract Expressionists who in 1949 founded the Club, a group of avant-garde artists who gathered in Greenwich Village to discuss and debate art. They organized lectures, concerts, and performances and held regular roundtable discussions to rethink the relationship of art to politics and urban life. In this context Tworkov\u2019s compositions reached their most chaotic and irregular. Yet even in these works, he applied the paint so thickly that despite their haphazard appearance, the brushstrokes produced solid blocks of color reminiscent of his earlier paintings. This predilection for more orderly compositions eventually caused Tworkov to distance himself from De Kooning and Abstract Expressionism in the late 1950s. Indeed, throughout his career, he remained torn between gestural and geometric abstraction. Tworkov eventually resolved this conflict by adopting a disciplined abstraction that combined irregular brushstrokes, ruler-drawn lines, and gridded patterns.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Biala Podlaska", "artistBirthDate": "1900", "artistDeathDate": "1982"}}, "545": {"paintingDate": "1918", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/54.1360_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. His first exhibition of paintings was held in 1908 in the Hague. In the early 1910s he wrote poetry and established himself as an art critic. From 1914 to 1916 van Doesburg served in the Dutch army, after which time he settled in Leiden and began his collaboration with the architects J. J. P. Oud and Jan Wils. In 1917 they founded the group De Stijl and the periodical of the same name; other original members were Vilmos Husz\u00e1r, Piet Mondrian, Bart van der Leck, and Georges Vantongerloo. Van Doesburg executed decorations for Oud\u2019s De Vonk project in Noordwijkerhout in 1917.\nIn 1920 he resumed his writing, using the pen name I. K. Bonset and later Aldo Camini. Van Doesburg visited Berlin and Weimar in 1921 and the following year taught at the Weimar Bauhaus, where he associated with Raoul Hausmann, Le Corbusier, Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, and Hans Richter. He was interested in Dada at this time and worked with Kurt Schwitters as well as Jean Arp, Tristan Tzara, and others on the review M\u00e9cano in 1922. Beginning in 1869, he worked for a firm of art dealers and at various short-lived jobs. By 1877 Van Gogh had begun religious studies, and from 1878 to 1880 he was an evangelist in the Borinage, a poor mining district in Belgium. While working as an evangelist, he decided to become an artist. Van Gogh admired the work of Jean Fran\u00e7ois Millet and Honor\u00e9 Daumier, and his early subjects were primarily peasants depicted in dark colors. He lived in Brussels and in various parts of the Netherlands before moving to Paris in February 1886.\nIn Paris he lived with his brother, Theo, and encountered Impressionist and Post-Impressionist painting. Van Gogh worked briefly at Fernand Cormon\u2019s atelier, where he met Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec. The artist also met Emile Bernard, Edgar Degas, Paul Gauguin, Camille Pissarro, and Paul Signac at that time. Flowers, portraits, and scenes of Montmartre, as well as a brighter palette, replaced his earlier subject matter and tonalities.
