He received a BFA in 1958 from the California College of Arts and Crafts (now California College of the Arts) and an MFA from Mills College, both in Oakland. His paintings are subsumed by a type of California spirit evident in their vibrant colors, which are reminiscent of Technicolor films or commercial photography. One of the 13 seminal Photorealist painters, McLean is also one of the foremost painters of horses in contemporary art.\nMcLean\u2019s large-scale canvases exhibit the slick finish and exaggerated accuracy typical of Photorealism. An offshoot of Pop art that emerged in the United States during the late 1960s, the movement was pioneered by McLean as well as such artists as Chuck Close, Richard Estes, Audrey Flack, and Malcolm Morley. McLean\u2019s major body of painting resulted from translations of color Kodachromes, which in turn were based on black-and-white photographs, as featured in monthly magazines dedicated to horse breeding and showmanship. With technical mastery belied by the obvious nod to his photographic source, McLean transforms the banal yet sentimentalized poses into keen statements on the distortions of perspective presented by photographs and the mass media.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Hoquiam", "artistBirthDate": "1934", "artistDeathDate": ""}}, "352": {"paintingDate": "1941", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/72.1991_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on canvas", "paintingName": "Years of Fear", "paintingNo": 352, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Civitavecchia", "artistDeathCountry": "Italy", "artistName": "Matta", "artistBirthCountry": "Chile", "biography": "Roberto Antonio Sebasti\u00e1n Matta Echaurren was born in Santiago, Chile, on November 11, 1911 or 1912 (Matta claimed the former, but other sources point to the following year). Raised by a prominent Roman Catholic family of Spanish and Franco-Basque origin, he studied architecture at the Colegio del Sagrado Coraz\u00f3n and Pontificia Universidad Cat\u00f3lica de Chile, both in Santiago. Seeking work, he moved to Europe in 1933, taking a position as a draftsman in the architectural studio of Le Corbusier in Paris, which he held until 1937. During this time, while visiting family in Spain and Portugal, Matta was introduced to the poets Federico Garc\u00eda Lorca, Gabriela Mistral, and Pablo Neruda. Through Garc\u00eda Lorca, Matta became familiar with Surrealism and received an introduction to Salvador Dal\u00ed, who in turn introduced him to Andr\u00e9 Breton. Around 1937, having shown Breton his fantastical architectural drawings, Matta joined the Surrealist group. He experimented with automatic writing alongside Yves Tanguy and Gordon Onslow-Ford, and in 1938 made his first paintings, called \u201cinscapes\u201d or \u201cpsychological morphologies,\u201d characterized by bright colors and the fusion of architectural space and biomorphic forms. \nIn 1939 Matta moved to the United States. Being multilingual and one of the youngest Surrealist expatriates, he quickly formed relationships with the new generation of New York painters. While living in the city, he explored automatic painting with artists such as William Baziotes, Arshile Gorky, and Robert Motherwell. Due to these relationships, Matta is often credited with playing an integral role in the development of Abstract Expressionism. During the mid-1940s Matta regularly visited with Marcel Duchamp, and he mostly disengaged from the American scene since his style increasingly encompassed anthropomorphic figuration instead of pure abstraction. \nIn 1948 Matta returned to Paris, where he was surprised to find that he had been expelled from the Surrealist group. He became less interested in representing his inner self through personal symbols and more concerned with expressing universal social experiences through recognizable forms. From 1950 to 1954 Matta lived in Rome, before returning once again to Paris. He became a French citizen in 1969. In the 1960s and 1970s Matta became involved in Latin American politics, supporting the Cuban revolutionaries, as well as the pro-government mural painters surrounding Chilean president Salvador Allende. He continued to paint and exhibit throughout his later years while living between London, Milan, Paris, and Tarquinia, Italy.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Santiago", "artistBirthDate": "1911", "artistDeathDate": "2002"}}, "351": {"paintingDate": "1916", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/82.2946_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. He grew up in Bohain-en-Vermandois and studied law in Paris from 1887 to 1888. By 1891 he had abandoned law and started to paint. In Paris Matisse studied art briefly at the Acad\u00e9mie Julian and then at the \u00c9cole des Beaux-Arts with Gustave Moreau.\nIn 1901 Matisse exhibited at the Salon des Ind\u00e9pendants in Paris and met another future leader of the Fauve movement, Maurice de Vlaminck. His first solo show took place at the Galerie Vollard in 1904. Both Leo and Gertrude Stein, as well as Etta and Claribel Cone, began to collect Matisse\u2019s work at that time. Like many avant-garde artists in Paris, Matisse was receptive to a broad range of influences. He was one of the first painters to take an interest in \u201cprimitive\u201d art. Matisse abandoned the palette of the Impressionists and established his characteristic style, with its flat, brilliant color and fluid line. His subjects were primarily women, interiors, and still lifes. In 1913 his work was included in the Armory Show in New York. By 1923 two Russians, Sergei Shchukin and Ivan Morozov, had purchased nearly 50 of his paintings.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Le Cateau-Cambr\u00e9sis", "artistBirthDate": "1869", "artistDeathDate": "1954"}}, "350": {"paintingDate": "1909\u201312", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/84.3252_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. He grew up in Bohain-en-Vermandois and studied law in Paris from 1887 to 1888. By 1891 he had abandoned law and started to paint. In Paris Matisse studied art briefly at the Acad\u00e9mie Julian and then at the \u00c9cole des Beaux-Arts with Gustave Moreau.\nIn 1901 Matisse exhibited at the Salon des Ind\u00e9pendants in Paris and met another future leader of the Fauve movement, Maurice de Vlaminck. His first solo show took place at the Galerie Vollard in 1904. Both Leo and Gertrude Stein, as well as Etta and Claribel Cone, began to collect Matisse\u2019s work at that time. Like many avant-garde artists in Paris, Matisse was receptive to a broad range of influences. He was one of the first painters to take an interest in \u201cprimitive\u201d art. Matisse abandoned the palette of the Impressionists and established his characteristic style, with its flat, brilliant color and fluid line. His subjects were primarily women, interiors, and still lifes. In 1913 his work was included in the Armory Show in New York. By 1923 two Russians, Sergei Shchukin and Ivan Morozov, had purchased nearly 50 of his paintings.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Le Cateau-Cambr\u00e9sis", "artistBirthDate": "1869", "artistDeathDate": "1954"}}, "359": {"paintingDate": "1995", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/2001.220_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Acrylic on canvas", "paintingName": "Santa Cruz", "paintingNo": 359, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Beatriz Milhazes", "artistBirthCountry": "Brazil", "biography": "Beatriz Milhazes was born in Rio de Janeiro in 1960. She studied public communication at Faculdades Integradas H\u00e9lio Alonso University, Rio de Janeiro (1978\u201381), and attended the city\u2019s Escola de artes visuais do Parque Lage (1980\u201382). In paintings, prints, and architectural installations that marry highly saturated color harmonies with geometric abstraction, Milhazes demonstrates an allegiance to both European and Brazilian modernism. She cites Henri Matisse, Piet Mondrian, and Tarsila do Amaral as her three primary influences, and all three figures are a strong presence within her work.\nIn the mid-1990s, Milhazes adopted an idiosyncratic method of collaging paint that has remained her signature technique. First, she paints a vibrantly colored abstract design onto a transparent sheet of plastic. She sticks this sheet to the canvas and then peels it off, leaving the layer of paint. Milhazes repeats this process many times for each work, creating a multilayered yet flat picture that seems to collapse together several moments in time. The sequential steps of this method remain visible in the finished piece, inviting close looking and intimate connection. Milhazes has said, \u201cI love painting, but I do not want the texture of the brushstrokes or the \u2018hand\u2019 of the painter to be visible on my canvases.\u201d\u00b9 Both this love of painting and the consequences of her technique are richly evident in the collaged-on designs, which retain an organic feel in their wildly colorful combination of graceful arabesques, geometric abstraction, and floral patterns. \nMilhazes\u2019s first major museum exhibition was organized in 2001 by Ikon Gallery, Birmingham, England, and traveled later that year to the Birmingham Museum of Art, Alabama. Her work was included in the S\u00e3o Paulo Biennial in 2002 and 2004, and in 2003 she represented Brazil at the Venice Biennale. In 2009, the Fondation Cartier pour l\u2019art contemporain, Paris, mounted a large-scale retrospective that included two new, site-specific installations on the building\u2019s exterior glass walls. Milhazes has created several public art projects, including G\u00e1vea (2004) at the Selfridges department store in Manchester, Peace and Love (2005\u201306) at the Gloucester Road tube station in London, Maracolouco (2008) at the Tokyo Museum of Contemporary Art, and Bailinho (2008) at the Pinacoteca do estado de S\u00e3o Paulo. Milhazes lives and works in Rio de Janeiro.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Rio de Janeiro", "artistBirthDate": "1960", "artistDeathDate": ""}}, "358": {"paintingDate": "1995\u201396", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/2001.219_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Acrylic on canvas", "paintingName": "In Albis", "paintingNo": 358, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Beatriz Milhazes", "artistBirthCountry": "Brazil", "biography": "Beatriz Milhazes was born in Rio de Janeiro in 1960. She studied public communication at Faculdades Integradas H\u00e9lio Alonso University, Rio de Janeiro (1978\u201381), and attended the city\u2019s Escola de artes visuais do Parque Lage (1980\u201382). In paintings, prints, and architectural installations that marry highly saturated color harmonies with geometric abstraction, Milhazes demonstrates an allegiance to both European and Brazilian modernism. She cites Henri Matisse, Piet Mondrian, and Tarsila do Amaral as her three primary influences, and all three figures are a strong presence within her work.\nIn the mid-1990s, Milhazes adopted an idiosyncratic method of collaging paint that has remained her signature technique. First, she paints a vibrantly colored abstract design onto a transparent sheet of plastic. She sticks this sheet to the canvas and then peels it off, leaving the layer of paint. Milhazes repeats this process many times for each work, creating a multilayered yet flat picture that seems to collapse together several moments in time. The sequential steps of this method remain visible in the finished piece, inviting close looking and intimate connection. Milhazes has said, \u201cI love painting, but I do not want the texture of the brushstrokes or the \u2018hand\u2019 of the painter to be visible on my canvases.\u201d\u00b9 Both this love of painting and the consequences of her technique are richly evident in the collaged-on designs, which retain an organic feel in their wildly colorful combination of graceful arabesques, geometric abstraction, and floral patterns. \nMilhazes\u2019s first major museum exhibition was organized in 2001 by Ikon Gallery, Birmingham, England, and traveled later that year to the Birmingham Museum of Art, Alabama. Her work was included in the S\u00e3o Paulo Biennial in 2002 and 2004, and in 2003 she represented Brazil at the Venice Biennale. In 2009, the Fondation Cartier pour l\u2019art contemporain, Paris, mounted a large-scale retrospective that included two new, site-specific installations on the building\u2019s exterior glass walls. Milhazes has created several public art projects, including G\u00e1vea (2004) at the Selfridges department store in Manchester, Peace and Love (2005\u201306) at the Gloucester Road tube station in London, Maracolouco (2008) at the Tokyo Museum of Contemporary Art, and Bailinho (2008) at the Pinacoteca do estado de S\u00e3o Paulo. Milhazes lives and works in Rio de Janeiro.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Rio de Janeiro", "artistBirthDate": "1960", "artistDeathDate": ""}}, "216": {"paintingDate": "1921", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/46.1050_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on canvas", "paintingName": "Circles on Black", "paintingNo": 216, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Neuilly-sur-Seine", "artistDeathCountry": "France", "artistName": "Vasily Kandinsky", "artistBirthCountry": "", "biography": "Vasily Kandinsky was born on December 4, 1866, in Moscow. From 1886 through 1892 he studied law and economics at the University of Moscow, where he lectured after graduation. In 1896 he declined a teaching position in order to study art in Munich with Anton Azbe from 1897 to 1899 and at the Kunstakademie with Franz von Stuck in 1900. Kandinsky taught in 1901\u201303 at the art school of the Phalanx, a group he cofounded in Munich. One of his students, Gabriele M\u00fcnter, would be his companion until 1914. In 1902 Kandinsky exhibited for the first time with the Berlin Secession and produced his first woodcuts. In 1903 and 1904 he began his travels in Italy, the Netherlands, and North Africa and his visits to Russia. He showed at the Salon d\u2019Automne in Paris from 1904.\nIn 1909 Kandinsky was elected president of the newly founded Neue K\u00fcnstlervereinigung M\u00fcnchen (NKVM). The group\u2019s first show took place at Heinrich Thannhauser\u2019s Moderne Galerie in Munich in 1909. In 1911 Kandinsky and Franz Marc began to make plans for Der Blaue Reiter Almanac, although the publication would not appear until the following year. Kandinsky\u2019s On the Spiritual in Art was published in December 1911. He and Marc withdrew from the NKVM in that month, and shortly thereafter the Blaue Reiter group\u2019s first exhibition was held at the Moderne Galerie. In 1912 the second Blaue Reiter show was held at the Galerie Hans Goltz, Munich. Kandinsky\u2019s first solo show was held at Der Sturm gallery in Berlin in 1912. In 1913 one of his works was included in the Armory Show in New York and the Erste deutsche Herbstsalon at the Der Sturm gallery in Berlin. Kandinsky lived in Russia from 1914 to 1921, principally in Moscow, where he held a position at the People\u2019s Commissariat of Education.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Moscow", "artistBirthDate": "1866", "artistDeathDate": "1944"}}, "217": {"paintingDate": "1922", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/76.2553.34_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. From 1886 through 1892 he studied law and economics at the University of Moscow, where he lectured after graduation. In 1896 he declined a teaching position in order to study art in Munich with Anton Azbe from 1897 to 1899 and at the Kunstakademie with Franz von Stuck in 1900. Kandinsky taught in 1901\u201303 at the art school of the Phalanx, a group he cofounded in Munich. One of his students, Gabriele M\u00fcnter, would be his companion until 1914. In 1902 Kandinsky exhibited for the first time with the Berlin Secession and produced his first woodcuts. In 1903 and 1904 he began his travels in Italy, the Netherlands, and North Africa and his visits to Russia. He showed at the Salon d\u2019Automne in Paris from 1904.\nIn 1909 Kandinsky was elected president of the newly founded Neue K\u00fcnstlervereinigung M\u00fcnchen (NKVM). The group\u2019s first show took place at Heinrich Thannhauser\u2019s Moderne Galerie in Munich in 1909. In 1911 Kandinsky and Franz Marc began to make plans for Der Blaue Reiter Almanac, although the publication would not appear until the following year. Kandinsky\u2019s On the Spiritual in Art was published in December 1911. He and Marc withdrew from the NKVM in that month, and shortly thereafter the Blaue Reiter group\u2019s first exhibition was held at the Moderne Galerie. In 1912 the second Blaue Reiter show was held at the Galerie Hans Goltz, Munich. Kandinsky\u2019s first solo show was held at Der Sturm gallery in Berlin in 1912. In 1913 one of his works was included in the Armory Show in New York and the Erste deutsche Herbstsalon at the Der Sturm gallery in Berlin. Kandinsky lived in Russia from 1914 to 1921, principally in Moscow, where he held a position at the People\u2019s Commissariat of Education.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Moscow", "artistBirthDate": "1866", "artistDeathDate": "1944"}}, "214": {"paintingDate": "1913", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/43.921_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on burlap", "paintingName": "Nude Model in the Studio", "paintingNo": 289, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Gif-sur-Yvette", "artistDeathCountry": "France", "artistName": "Fernand L\u00e9ger", "artistBirthCountry": "", "biography": "Joseph Fernand Henri L\u00e9ger was born on February 4, 1881, in Argentan, France. After apprenticing with an architect in Caen from 1897 to 1899, L\u00e9ger settled in Paris in 1900 and supported himself as an architectural draftsman. He was refused entrance to the \u00c9cole des Beaux-Arts but nevertheless attended classes there beginning in 1903; he also studied at the Acad\u00e9mie Julian. L\u00e9ger\u2019s earliest-known works, which date from 1905, were primarily influenced by Impressionism. The experience of seeing the Paul C\u00e9zanne retrospective at the Salon d\u2019Automne in 1907 and his contact with the early Cubism of Pablo Picasso and Georges Braque had an extremely significant impact on the development of his personal style. From 1911 to 1914 L\u00e9ger\u2019s work became increasingly abstract, and he started to limit his color to the primaries and black and white. In 1912 he was given his first solo show at Galerie Kahnweiler, Paris.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "", "artistBirthDate": "", "artistDeathDate": "1955"}}, "288": {"paintingDate": "1912", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/38.521_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. After apprenticing with an architect in Caen from 1897 to 1899, L\u00e9ger settled in Paris in 1900 and supported himself as an architectural draftsman. He was refused entrance to the \u00c9cole des Beaux-Arts but nevertheless attended classes there beginning in 1903; he also studied at the Acad\u00e9mie Julian. L\u00e9ger\u2019s earliest-known works, which date from 1905, were primarily influenced by Impressionism. The experience of seeing the Paul C\u00e9zanne retrospective at the Salon d\u2019Automne in 1907 and his contact with the early Cubism of Pablo Picasso and Georges Braque had an extremely significant impact on the development of his personal style. From 1911 to 1914 L\u00e9ger\u2019s work became increasingly abstract, and he started to limit his color to the primaries and black and white. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on canvas", "paintingName": "Night Flight", "paintingNo": 4, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Zurich", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Afro (Afro Basaldella)", "artistBirthCountry": "Italy", "biography": "Afro Libio Basaldella (known as Afro) was born on March 4, 1912, in Udine, Italy. His siblings shared his interest in art; he devoted himself to painting while his older brothers Dino and Mirko became sculptors. Afro studied in Florence and Venice, and in 1932 his first solo exhibition was held at Galleria del Milione, Milan. In 1933 Afro started working in a figurative style rich in symbolic accents and pale and ethereal tones, akin to that of the Scuola Romana (Roman School), with which he was temporarily affiliated. Afro moved to Rome in 1938, but served in the Italian army (and participated in the anti-Fascist Resistance) during World War II. He also taught mosaic design at the Accademia di belle arti, Venice, and his work took a new slant, as figuration gradually gave way to a growing interest in Cubism. \nReturning to Rome in 1945, Afro encountered tensions between proponents of abstraction and those who favored realism, but he was only marginally involved in these controversies. By the end of the decade he had developed a strand of abstraction based on intersecting geometric planes and expressive juxtapositions of color and light. Increasingly weary of the polemics among painters in Italy, Afro turned his attention to the American scene. In 1950 he traveled to New York for the opening of a group show of Italian artists at the Catherine Viviano Gallery, a venue that hosted his first U.S. solo exhibition later that year and regular exhibitions of his work through 1968.\nFrom 1952 Afro's painting took a new direction, adding fluid signs, rounded contours, and a brighter palette and replacing the angular forms and quasi-monochromatic pictorial language of earlier years. That same year he joined the Gruppo degli Otto Pittori Italiani (Group of eight Italian painters, 1952\u201354), whose \"abstract-concrete\" leanings represented an alternative to the Italian abstraction-realism polarization. The group exhibited together at the 1952 Venice Biennale, but by 1954 Afro had distanced himself from the Otto\u2014a move that coincided with the introduction of an increasingly dynamic gesture in his works. More dramatic and spontaneous, Afro's late 1950s works testify to his growing interest in Abstract Expressionism, amplified by his friendship with Willem de Kooning, who stayed in Afro's studio in Rome in 1959, and Afro's frequent visits to the United States. James Johnson Sweeney, art critic and former director of the Guggenheim Museum, authored an early monograph on Afro in 1961. Afro's paintings of the 1960s were increasingly gestural, a tendency that he reversed at the end of the decade when his works became more synthetic and geometric. \n", "artistBirthPlace": "Udine", "artistBirthDate": "1912", "artistDeathDate": "1976"}}, "281": {"paintingDate": "1946", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/93.4233_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. From 1889 to 1892 he studied at the Prague Art Academy. During this time he painted historical and patriotic themes. In 1892, Kupka enrolled at the Akademie der Bildenden K\u00fcnste, Vienna, where he concentrated on symbolic and allegorical subjects. He exhibited at the Kunstverein, Vienna, in 1894. His involvement with theosophy and Eastern philosophy dates from this period. By spring 1896 Kupka had settled in Paris; there he attended the Acad\u00e9mie Julian briefly and then studied with Jean-Pierre Laurens at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts.\nKupka worked as an illustrator of books and posters and, during his early years in Paris, became known for his satirical drawings for newspapers and magazines. In 1906 he settled in Puteaux, a suburb of Paris, and that same year exhibited for the first time at the Salon d\u2019Automne. Kupka was deeply impressed by the first Futurist manifesto, published in 1909 in Le Figaro. Kupka\u2019s work became increasingly abstract around 1910\u201311, reflecting his theories of motion, color, and the relationship between music and painting. In 1911 he attended meetings of the Puteaux group. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on canvas", "paintingName": "Zambezia, Zambezia", "paintingNo": 285, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Paris", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Wifredo Lam", "artistBirthCountry": "Cuba", "biography": "Wifredo Oscar de la Concepci\u00f3n Lam y Castilla was born December 8, 1902, in Sagua la Grande, Cuba. In 1916, his family moved to Havana, where he attended the Escuela de Bellas Artes. During the early 1920s, he exhibited at the Sal\u00f3n de la Asociaci\u00f3n de Pintores y Escultores in Havana. In 1923, Lam moved to Madrid, where he studied at the studio of Fernando Alvarez de Sotomayor, the Director of the Museo del Prado (and a teacher of Salvador Dal\u00ed). In 1929, Lam married Eva Piriz, who died of tuberculosis two years later, as did their young son. This tragic event may have contributed to the dark and brooding appearance of much of Lam\u2019s later work.\nIn the early 1930s, the effects of Surrealism were evident in Lam\u2019s work, as was the influence of Henri Matisse and possibly Joaqu\u00edn Torres-Garc\u00eda. In 1936, a traveling exhibition of the work of Pablo Picasso shown in Barcelona, Bilbao, and Madrid proved inspirational to Lam both artistically and politically. He moved to Paris in 1938, where Picasso took him under his wing and encouraged his interest in African art and primitive masks. During that year, he also traveled to Mexico, where he stayed with Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera. Lam\u2019s own multicultural heritage (as the son of a Chinese father and a mother of mixed African, Indian, and European descent) and his involvement with Santer\u00eda, a religion rooted in African culture, would soon become integral to his work. By the late 1930s, Lam was associated with the Surrealists. He had his first solo show at the Galerie Pierre Loeb in Paris in 1939, and his work was exhibited with Picasso\u2019s at the Perls Galleries, New York.\nDuring World War II, Lam spent most of his time in the Caribbean, along with Claude L\u00e9vi-Strauus, Andr\u00e9 Masson, and Andr\u00e9 Breton, whose poem \u201cFata Morgana\u201d Lam illustrated in 1940. Lam eventually made his way back to Havana in 1941. His first year in Cuba marked a watershed in his artistic development; he was introduced to the theories of Carl Jung, and by the end of 1942 he had begun his powerful painting Jungle. Lam\u2019s exploration of mythic images paralleled that of his contemporaries in New York, the Abstract Expressionists, though Lam used specific subject matter. Lam created his own style by fusing Surrealism and Cubism with the spirit and forms of the Caribbean.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Sagua La Grande", "artistBirthDate": "1902", "artistDeathDate": "1982"}}, "284": {"paintingDate": "1950", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/58.1525_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. In 1916, his family moved to Havana, where he attended the Escuela de Bellas Artes. During the early 1920s, he exhibited at the Sal\u00f3n de la Asociaci\u00f3n de Pintores y Escultores in Havana. In 1923, Lam moved to Madrid, where he studied at the studio of Fernando Alvarez de Sotomayor, the Director of the Museo del Prado (and a teacher of Salvador Dal\u00ed). In 1929, Lam married Eva Piriz, who died of tuberculosis two years later, as did their young son. This tragic event may have contributed to the dark and brooding appearance of much of Lam\u2019s later work.\nIn the early 1930s, the effects of Surrealism were evident in Lam\u2019s work, as was the influence of Henri Matisse and possibly Joaqu\u00edn Torres-Garc\u00eda. In 1936, a traveling exhibition of the work of Pablo Picasso shown in Barcelona, Bilbao, and Madrid proved inspirational to Lam both artistically and politically. He moved to Paris in 1938, where Picasso took him under his wing and encouraged his interest in African art and primitive masks. During that year, he also traveled to Mexico, where he stayed with Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera. Lam\u2019s own multicultural heritage (as the son of a Chinese father and a mother of mixed African, Indian, and European descent) and his involvement with Santer\u00eda, a religion rooted in African culture, would soon become integral to his work. By the late 1930s, Lam was associated with the Surrealists. Lam eventually made his way back to Havana in 1941. His first year in Cuba marked a watershed in his artistic development; he was introduced to the theories of Carl Jung, and by the end of 1942 he had begun his powerful painting Jungle. Lam\u2019s exploration of mythic images paralleled that of his contemporaries in New York, the Abstract Expressionists, though Lam used specific subject matter. Lam created his own style by fusing Surrealism and Cubism with the spirit and forms of the Caribbean.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Sagua La Grande", "artistBirthDate": "1902", "artistDeathDate": "1982"}}, "287": {"paintingDate": "2010", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/2011.7_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil and mineral pigment on canvas", "paintingName": "Dialogue", "paintingNo": 287, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Lee Ufan", "artistBirthCountry": "Korea", "biography": "Lee rose to prominence in the late 1960s as the leading theorist and practitioner of Mono-ha, a Japanese art movement that grew out of the anti-authoritarian and anti-colonialist tumult of the postwar period. It emphasized the use of raw physical materials left to scatter, lean, drop, or break according to their situation. Applying structuralism, phenomenology, and Asian metaphysics in dialogue with international Post-Minimalist practices, Arte Povera, Nouveau R\u00e9alisme, and Land art, he developed a radical artistic language revolving around the notion of encounter\u2014seeing the bare existence of what is actually before us and focusing on \"the world as it is.\"\nLee's sculptural works from this period, which he refers as k\u014dz\u014d, or \"living structures,\" are distinguished by a move away from expression and toward a detached act of arranging or mediating. These works are often titled Relatum (1968\u2013), a Latin term denoting \"relation,\" and operate in an expanded field where the artist's creative gesture resides in the choreographed confluence of the object, the viewer, and the resonant surrounding space. Similarly, his paintings incorporate vast areas of white space that function as a productive site of possibility rather than a void or negative space.\nIn the early 1970s, Lee received significant attention at Tokyo's leading galleries and museums and began exhibiting in West Germany and France, including at the 1971 Paris Youth Biennale, which introduced Mono-ha to Europe and led him to establish a studio in Paris that year. In the wake of Abstract Expressionism in the United States and Art Informel in Europe, Lee developed the iconic From Point and From Line series (1972\u201384). Here Lee employed a monochrome palette and iterative brush strokes moving horizontally or vertically across the canvas to chart the passage of lived time. This body of work garnered critical acclaim in Asia and became especially influential in his home country of Korea, where he became a seminal figure in the tansaekhwa (monochrome painting) school.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Kyongnam", "artistBirthDate": "1936", "artistDeathDate": ""}}, "286": {"paintingDate": "1912", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/53.1362_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on canvas", "paintingName": "Glass", "paintingNo": 286, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Fontenay-aux-Roses", "artistDeathCountry": "France", "artistName": "Mikhail Larionov", "artistBirthCountry": "Moldova", "biography": "Mikhail Larionov was born in Tiraspol, a city near Odessa, Ukraine, in 1881. He completed secondary school at the Voskresensky Technical High School in Moscow, and at the age of 17 began studying at the Moscow School of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture. In 1900, he met fellow student Natalia Goncharova, and the two began their long-term collaboration and partnership. His early work included Impressionist landscapes, several of which he exhibited at the Salon d'Automne in Paris in 1906. Exposed to and influenced by contemporary French painting, he began using strategies of Symbolism, and in 1908 co-organized an exhibition of modern French painting in Moscow with the arts journal Zolotoye runo (Golden Fleece), which included work of the Post-Impressionists and Fauves. Larionov's Evening after the Rain (Posle dozhdia, 1909) employs the bright color and coarse brushwork of the latter. In 1910, he cofounded the Bubnovyi valet (Jack of Diamonds) group, composed of several Russian artists with an interest in Primitivism and the appropriation of provincial folk art. In 1911 he cofounded Oslinyi Khvost (Donkey's Tail) with Goncharova, a second and more radical primitivist group that was much more focused on Russian primitivism, to the exclusion of foreign influence. In 1912 the group staged its first exhibition at Moscow's Stroganov Art Institute, and in 1913 published the related journal Oslinyi khvost I mishen (Donkey's Tail and Target).\nLater that year, Larionov initiated two highly influential movements: Rayism and Neo-Primitivism. Rayism, the tenets of which were outlined in three 1913 manifestos by Larionov, was inspired by Italian Futurism and was the first emergence of near-abstract art in Russia; Rayonisme (Domination du rouge) (Rayonist Composition: Domination of Red, 1912\u201313) is an early example of the style's pre-Constructivist mass of slanting lines and painted rays of light. Neo-Primitivism, for which Larionov became known among the European avant-garde, was a fusion of his interests in Fauvism and Expressionism. The style is evident in Boulevard Venus (Promenade [V\u00e9nus sur un boulevard], 1913), a cubo-futurist portrait of a dress-and-heels-clad prostitute in motion, which combined broad strokes of red, green, and yellow paint with multiple perspectives. Larionov and Goncharova left Russia in 1915 for Lausanne and Paris, touring with Sergei Diaghilev's Ballets Russes: Larionov's commissions for Diaghilev included designs for the ballets The Midnight Sun (Soleil de nuit) in Switzerland in 1915 and Russian Tales (Contes russes) in Paris in 1917; the latter, sumptuous and based on Russian folktales, solidified his international reputation.\nBy 1919, he had settled in Paris, where he often collaborated with Cubist and Dada painters and poets, and organized the first major exhibition of modern French art for the Soviet Union in 1928 at Moscow's Tretyakov Gallery. He also began to focus on graphic work: he published in the fourth Bauhaus portfolio, and contributed illustrations to Vladimir Mayakovsky's canonical poem, \"The Sun,\" in 1923. Throughout the 1920s, he continued to work for Diaghilev as a set designer and artistic advisor, returning to painting (primarily figurative oils) only after Diaghilev's death in 1929. However, he continued to study dance and occasionally design for the ballet. After gaining French citizenship in 1938, falling into relative obscurity, and spending the war years confined to his and Goncharova's apartment due to poor health, he suffered a stroke in 1950 and spent his remaining years in poverty, dying in a rest home at Fontenay-aux-Roses near Paris in 1964.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Tiraspol", "artistBirthDate": "1881", "artistDeathDate": "1964"}}, "263": {"paintingDate": "1937", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/48.1172.59_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Charcoal on cloth,", "paintingName": "Arches of the Bridge Stepping Out of Line", "paintingNo": 263, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Muralto-Locarno", "artistDeathCountry": "Switzerland", "artistName": "Paul Klee", "artistBirthCountry": "Switzerland", "biography": "Paul Klee was born on December 18, 1879, in M\u00fcnchenbuchsee, Switzerland, into a family of musicians. His childhood love of music was always to remain profoundly important in his life and work. From 1898 to 1901 Klee studied in Munich, first with Heinrich Knirr, then at the Kunstakademie under Franz von Stuck. Upon completing his schooling, he traveled to Italy. It was the first in a series of trips abroad that nourished his visual sensibilities. He settled in Bern in 1902. A series of his satirical etchings was exhibited at the Munich Secession in 1906. That same year Klee married Lily Stumpf, a pianist, and moved to Munich. There he gained exposure to Modern art. Klee\u2019s work was shown at the Kunstmuseum Bern in 1910 and at Moderne Galerie, Munich, in 1911.\nKlee met Alexej Jawlensky, Vasily Kandinsky, August Macke, Franz Marc, and other avant-garde figures in 1911; he participated in important shows of advanced art, including the second Blaue Reiter (Blue Rider) exhibition at Galerie Hans Goltz, Munich, in 1912, and the Erste deutsche Herbstsalon at the Der Sturm Gallery, Berlin, in 1913. In 1912 he visited Paris for the second time, where he saw the work of Georges Braque and Pablo Picasso, and met Robert Delaunay. Klee helped found the Neue M\u00fcnchner Secession in 1914. Color became central to his art only after a revelatory trip to Tunisia in 1914.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "M\u00fcnchenbuchsee", "artistBirthDate": "1879", "artistDeathDate": "1940"}}, "262": {"paintingDate": "1936", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/71.1960_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. His childhood love of music was always to remain profoundly important in his life and work. From 1898 to 1901 Klee studied in Munich, first with Heinrich Knirr, then at the Kunstakademie under Franz von Stuck. Upon completing his schooling, he traveled to Italy. It was the first in a series of trips abroad that nourished his visual sensibilities. He settled in Bern in 1902. A series of his satirical etchings was exhibited at the Munich Secession in 1906. That same year Klee married Lily Stumpf, a pianist, and moved to Munich. There he gained exposure to Modern art. Klee\u2019s work was shown at the Kunstmuseum Bern in 1910 and at Moderne Galerie, Munich, in 1911.\nKlee met Alexej Jawlensky, Vasily Kandinsky, August Macke, Franz Marc, and other avant-garde figures in 1911; he participated in important shows of advanced art, including the second Blaue Reiter (Blue Rider) exhibition at Galerie Hans Goltz, Munich, in 1912, and the Erste deutsche Herbstsalon at the Der Sturm Gallery, Berlin, in 1913. In 1912 he visited Paris for the second time, where he saw the work of Georges Braque and Pablo Picasso, and met Robert Delaunay. Klee helped found the Neue M\u00fcnchner Secession in 1914. Color became central to his art only after a revelatory trip to Tunisia in 1914.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "M\u00fcnchenbuchsee", "artistBirthDate": "1879", "artistDeathDate": "1940"}}, "260": {"paintingDate": "1930", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/48.1172.526_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Water-based paint and varnish over white lacquer on paper,", "paintingName": "Open Book", "paintingNo": 260, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Muralto-Locarno", "artistDeathCountry": "Switzerland", "artistName": "Paul Klee", "artistBirthCountry": "Switzerland", "biography": "Paul Klee was born on December 18, 1879, in M\u00fcnchenbuchsee, Switzerland, into a family of musicians. His childhood love of music was always to remain profoundly important in his life and work. From 1898 to 1901 Klee studied in Munich, first with Heinrich Knirr, then at the Kunstakademie under Franz von Stuck. Upon completing his schooling, he traveled to Italy. It was the first in a series of trips abroad that nourished his visual sensibilities. He settled in Bern in 1902. A series of his satirical etchings was exhibited at the Munich Secession in 1906. That same year Klee married Lily Stumpf, a pianist, and moved to Munich. There he gained exposure to Modern art. Klee\u2019s work was shown at the Kunstmuseum Bern in 1910 and at Moderne Galerie, Munich, in 1911.\nKlee met Alexej Jawlensky, Vasily Kandinsky, August Macke, Franz Marc, and other avant-garde figures in 1911; he participated in important shows of advanced art, including the second Blaue Reiter (Blue Rider) exhibition at Galerie Hans Goltz, Munich, in 1912, and the Erste deutsche Herbstsalon at the Der Sturm Gallery, Berlin, in 1913. In 1912 he visited Paris for the second time, where he saw the work of Georges Braque and Pablo Picasso, and met Robert Delaunay. Klee helped found the Neue M\u00fcnchner Secession in 1914. Color became central to his art only after a revelatory trip to Tunisia in 1914.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "M\u00fcnchenbuchsee", "artistBirthDate": "1879", "artistDeathDate": "1940"}}, "267": {"paintingDate": "1952", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/54.1403_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "7", "paintingName": "Painting No. 7", "paintingNo": 267, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "New York", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Franz Kline", "artistBirthCountry": "Pennsylvania", "biography": "Franz Kline was born on May 23, 1910, in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. He studied painting and drawing at Boston University (1931\u201335), and drafting and illustration at the Heatherley School of Fine Art, London (1937\u201338). After returning to the United States, he settled in New York, where he produced traditional cityscapes and interior scenes and, in the early 1940s, won awards at several National Academy of Design Annuals.\nKline soon began experimenting with small black-and-white brush drawings after Willem de Kooning introduced him to abstraction. At the end of the decade, De Kooning\u2019s use of a Bell-Opticon projector inspired Kline to project his brush drawings onto his studio wall, transforming them into large-scale ideograms. These experiments marked the beginning of Kline\u2019s characteristic abstractions incorporating powerful lines and rapidly developed gestures of black paint on white ground. Compositions such as Wotan (1950\u201351) prompted speculation about the influence of East Asian calligraphy on Kline\u2019s practice; he denied these claims, stating that he fully intended the images to evoke the known or recognizable while avoiding literal references. Kline employed intense tonal contrasts, often working at night under strong light. His use of housepainters\u2019 brushes produced tiny splatters and inflections on the canvas that enhanced the explosive quality of his black lines.\nLike many fellow Abstract Expressionists, such as De Kooning and Mark Rothko, Kline took his work in several different directions in the late 1950s. He produced a sequence of exceptionally large, horizontally oriented works known as the \u201cwall paintings\u201d (1959\u201361), the monumentality of which would be echoed in later paintings by Robert Motherwell and Clyfford Still. He also introduced harsh and strident color, as in King Oliver (1958). He spent a month in Europe, traveling mostly in Italy, in 1960. Two years later, at the peak of his career, Kline died of heart failure on May 13, 1962, in New York.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Wilkes-Barre", "artistBirthDate": "1910", "artistDeathDate": "1962"}}, "266": {"paintingDate": "ca.1960", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/GBM1997.8_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "1960", "paintingName": "Large Blue Anthropometry (ANT 105)", "paintingNo": 266, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Paris", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Yves Klein", "artistBirthCountry": "France", "biography": "Yves Klein was born on April 28, 1928, in Nice, France. From 1942 to 1946, he studied at the \u00c9cole nationale de la marine marchande and the \u00c9cole nationale des langues orientales vivantes (now Institut national des langues et civilisations orientales) and began practicing judo. At this time, he became friends with artist Arman and singer Claude Pascal and started to paint. Klein composed his first one-note Symphonie monotone (Monotone Symphony) in 1947. From 1948 to 1952, he traveled to Italy, the United Kingdom, Spain, and Japan. In 1955, Klein settled permanently in Paris, where he was given a solo exhibition at the Club des Solitaires. His monochrome paintings were shown at the Galerie Colette Allendy, Paris, in 1956.\nIn 1957, Klein entered his \u00e9poque bleue (blue period); this year a double exhibition of his work was held at the Galerie Iris Clert and the Galerie Colette Allendy, both in Paris. In 1958, Klein emptied the Galerie Iris Clert, repainted the walls white, and presented the emptiness of the space as a work of art in the groundbreaking conceptual exhibition The Void (La voide). Also that year, he began using nude models as \u201cliving paintbrushes,\u201d covering them in paint and instructing them in the pressing and dragging of their bodies across paper and canvas. These works, called Anthropometries (Anthropom\u00e9tries), recorded gestural impressions and the physical energy of the body. Also in 1957, Klein undertook a project for the decoration of the entrance hall of the new opera house in Gelsenkirchen, West Germany. He signed the first manifesto of the group Nouveaux R\u00e9alistes (New Realists, 1960\u201363), written in 1960 by critic Pierre Restany. In 1960, Klein patented International Klein Blue (IKB), a paint color he created with the help of a chemical retailer. Klein was inspired to develop IKB after searching for a shade of blue that effectively unlocked the endless void of space, eradicating the division of earth and sky. IKB, heavy in ultramarine, used a clear, colorless carrier (unlike traditional binders, which had a dulling effect) to suspend pure, dry pigment, maintaining the pigment\u2019s original intensity.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Nice", "artistBirthDate": "1928", "artistDeathDate": "1962"}}, "265": {"paintingDate": "1959", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/2000.28_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. He spent most of his youth in Vienna, where he entered the Kunstgewerbeschule in 1904 or 1905. While still a student, he painted fans and postcards for the Wiener Werkst\u00e4tte, which published his first book of poetry in 1908. That same year, Kokoschka was fiercely criticized for the works he exhibited in the Vienna Kunstschau and consequently was dismissed from the Kunstgewerbeschule. At this time, he attracted the attention of the architect Adolf Loos, who became his most vigorous supporter. In this early period, Kokoschka wrote plays that are considered among the first examples of expressionist drama.\nHis first solo show was held at the Galerie Paul Cassirer, Berlin, in 1910, followed later that year by another at the Museum Folkwang Essen. In 1910, he also began to contribute to Herwarth Walden\u2019s periodical Der Sturm. Kokoschka concentrated on portraiture, dividing his time between Berlin and Vienna from 1910 to 1914. In 1915, shortly after the outbreak of World War I, he volunteered to serve on the eastern front, where he was seriously wounded. Still recuperating in 1917, he settled in Dresden and in 1919 accepted a professorship at the Akademie there. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil with pebbles and sand on fine linen canvas", "paintingName": "The Bowl of Grapes", "paintingNo": 59, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Paris", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Georges Braque", "artistBirthCountry": "France", "biography": "Georges Braque was born on May 13, 1882, in Argenteuil-sur-Seine, France. He grew up in Le Havre and studied evenings at the \u00c9cole des Beaux-Arts there from about 1897 to 1899. He left for Paris to study under a master decorator to receive his craftsman certificate in 1901. From 1902 to 1904 he painted at the Acad\u00e9mie Humbert in Paris, where he met Marie Laurencin and Francis Picabia. By 1906 Braque\u2019s work was no longer Impressionist but Fauve in style; after spending that summer in Antwerp with Othon Friesz, he showed his Fauve work the following year in the Salon des Ind\u00e9pendants in Paris. His first solo show was at Daniel-Henri Kahnweiler\u2019s gallery in 1908. From 1909 Pablo Picasso and Braque worked together in developing Cubism; by 1911 their styles were extremely similar. In 1912 they started to incorporate collage elements into their paintings and to experiment with the papier coll\u00e9 (pasted paper) technique. Their artistic collaboration lasted until 1914. Braque served in the French army during World War I and was wounded; upon his recovery in 1917 he began a close friendship with Juan Gris.\nAfter World War I Braque\u2019s work became freer and less schematic. His fame grew in 1922 as a result of an exhibition at the Salon d\u2019Automne in Paris. In the mid-1920s Braque designed the decor for two Sergei Diaghilev ballets. By the end of the decade, he had returned to a more realistic interpretation of nature, although certain aspects of Cubism always remained present in his work. In 1931 Braque made his first engraved plasters and began to portray mythological subjects. His first important retrospective took place in 1933 at the Kunsthalle Basel. He won first prize at the Carnegie International, Pittsburgh, in 1937.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Argenteuil-sur-Seine", "artistBirthDate": "1882", "artistDeathDate": "1963"}}, "58": {"paintingDate": "1919", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/81.2821_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. He grew up in Le Havre and studied evenings at the \u00c9cole des Beaux-Arts there from about 1897 to 1899. He left for Paris to study under a master decorator to receive his craftsman certificate in 1901. From 1902 to 1904 he painted at the Acad\u00e9mie Humbert in Paris, where he met Marie Laurencin and Francis Picabia. By 1906 Braque\u2019s work was no longer Impressionist but Fauve in style; after spending that summer in Antwerp with Othon Friesz, he showed his Fauve work the following year in the Salon des Ind\u00e9pendants in Paris. His first solo show was at Daniel-Henri Kahnweiler\u2019s gallery in 1908. From 1909 Pablo Picasso and Braque worked together in developing Cubism; by 1911 their styles were extremely similar. In 1912 they started to incorporate collage elements into their paintings and to experiment with the papier coll\u00e9 (pasted paper) technique. Their artistic collaboration lasted until 1914. Braque served in the French army during World War I and was wounded; upon his recovery in 1917 he began a close friendship with Juan Gris.\nAfter World War I Braque\u2019s work became freer and less schematic. His fame grew in 1922 as a result of an exhibition at the Salon d\u2019Automne in Paris. In the mid-1920s Braque designed the decor for two Sergei Diaghilev ballets. By the end of the decade, he had returned to a more realistic interpretation of nature, although certain aspects of Cubism always remained present in his work. In 1931 Braque made his first engraved plasters and began to portray mythological subjects. His first important retrospective took place in 1933 at the Kunsthalle Basel. From 1902 to 1904 he painted at the Acad\u00e9mie Humbert in Paris, where he met Marie Laurencin and Francis Picabia. By 1906 Braque\u2019s work was no longer Impressionist but Fauve in style; after spending that summer in Antwerp with Othon Friesz, he showed his Fauve work the following year in the Salon des Ind\u00e9pendants in Paris. By the end of the decade, he had returned to a more realistic interpretation of nature, although certain aspects of Cubism always remained present in his work. He left for Paris to study under a master decorator to receive his craftsman certificate in 1901. From 1902 to 1904 he painted at the Acad\u00e9mie Humbert in Paris, where he met Marie Laurencin and Francis Picabia. By 1906 Braque\u2019s work was no longer Impressionist but Fauve in style; after spending that summer in Antwerp with Othon Friesz, he showed his Fauve work the following year in the Salon des Ind\u00e9pendants in Paris. His first solo show was at Daniel-Henri Kahnweiler\u2019s gallery in 1908. From 1909 Pablo Picasso and Braque worked together in developing Cubism; by 1911 their styles were extremely similar. In 1912 they started to incorporate collage elements into their paintings and to experiment with the papier coll\u00e9 (pasted paper) technique. Their artistic collaboration lasted until 1914. By the end of the decade, he had returned to a more realistic interpretation of nature, although certain aspects of Cubism always remained present in his work. In 1931 Braque made his first engraved plasters and began to portray mythological subjects. His first important retrospective took place in 1933 at the Kunsthalle Basel. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil with sand on fine linen canvas", "paintingName": "The Clarinet", "paintingNo": 57, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Paris", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Georges Braque", "artistBirthCountry": "France", "biography": "Georges Braque was born on May 13, 1882, in Argenteuil-sur-Seine, France. He grew up in Le Havre and studied evenings at the \u00c9cole des Beaux-Arts there from about 1897 to 1899. He left for Paris to study under a master decorator to receive his craftsman certificate in 1901. From 1902 to 1904 he painted at the Acad\u00e9mie Humbert in Paris, where he met Marie Laurencin and Francis Picabia. By 1906 Braque\u2019s work was no longer Impressionist but Fauve in style; after spending that summer in Antwerp with Othon Friesz, he showed his Fauve work the following year in the Salon des Ind\u00e9pendants in Paris. His first solo show was at Daniel-Henri Kahnweiler\u2019s gallery in 1908. From 1909 Pablo Picasso and Braque worked together in developing Cubism; by 1911 their styles were extremely similar. In 1912 they started to incorporate collage elements into their paintings and to experiment with the papier coll\u00e9 (pasted paper) technique. Their artistic collaboration lasted until 1914. Braque served in the French army during World War I and was wounded; upon his recovery in 1917 he began a close friendship with Juan Gris.\nAfter World War I Braque\u2019s work became freer and less schematic. His fame grew in 1922 as a result of an exhibition at the Salon d\u2019Automne in Paris. In the mid-1920s Braque designed the decor for two Sergei Diaghilev ballets. By the end of the decade, he had returned to a more realistic interpretation of nature, although certain aspects of Cubism always remained present in his work. In 1931 Braque made his first engraved plasters and began to portray mythological subjects. His first important retrospective took place in 1933 at the Kunsthalle Basel. He won first prize at the Carnegie International, Pittsburgh, in 1937.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Argenteuil-sur-Seine", "artistBirthDate": "1882", "artistDeathDate": "1963"}}, "56": {"paintingDate": "1909\u201310", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/54.1411_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on canvas", "paintingName": "Piano and Mandola", "paintingNo": 56, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Paris", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Georges Braque", "artistBirthCountry": "France", "biography": "Georges Braque was born on May 13, 1882, in Argenteuil-sur-Seine, France. He grew up in Le Havre and studied evenings at the \u00c9cole des Beaux-Arts there from about 1897 to 1899. He left for Paris to study under a master decorator to receive his craftsman certificate in 1901. From 1902 to 1904 he painted at the Acad\u00e9mie Humbert in Paris, where he met Marie Laurencin and Francis Picabia. By 1906 Braque\u2019s work was no longer Impressionist but Fauve in style; after spending that summer in Antwerp with Othon Friesz, he showed his Fauve work the following year in the Salon des Ind\u00e9pendants in Paris. His first solo show was at Daniel-Henri Kahnweiler\u2019s gallery in 1908. From 1909 Pablo Picasso and Braque worked together in developing Cubism; by 1911 their styles were extremely similar. In 1912 they started to incorporate collage elements into their paintings and to experiment with the papier coll\u00e9 (pasted paper) technique. Their artistic collaboration lasted until 1914. Braque served in the French army during World War I and was wounded; upon his recovery in 1917 he began a close friendship with Juan Gris.\nAfter World War I Braque\u2019s work became freer and less schematic. His fame grew in 1922 as a result of an exhibition at the Salon d\u2019Automne in Paris. In the mid-1920s Braque designed the decor for two Sergei Diaghilev ballets. By the end of the decade, he had returned to a more realistic interpretation of nature, although certain aspects of Cubism always remained present in his work. In 1931 Braque made his first engraved plasters and began to portray mythological subjects. His first important retrospective took place in 1933 at the Kunsthalle Basel. He won first prize at the Carnegie International, Pittsburgh, in 1937.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Argenteuil-sur-Seine", "artistBirthDate": "1882", "artistDeathDate": "1963"}}, "51": {"paintingDate": "1994", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/95.4485_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. During his school years in Kleve, Beuys was exposed to the work of Achilles Moortgat, whose studio he often visited, and was inspired by the sculptures of Wilhelm Lehmbruck. Beuys began to study medicine in 1940, but his studies were interrupted when he joined the army and served as a fighter pilot. During a mission in 1943, he was badly injured when his plane crashed in a desolate region of south Russia. This experience would resonate in all of his later work.\nAfter the war, he decided to dedicate his life to art. In 1947, he registered at the Staatliche Kunstakademie D\u00fcsseldorf, where he studied under Joseph Enseling and Ewald Matar\u00e9. After Beuys graduated in 1951, the brothers Franz Joseph and Hans van der Grinten began to collect his work. Eventually becoming his most important patrons, they organized his first solo show at their house in Kranenburg in 1953. Beuys was appointed professor of monumental sculpture at the Staatliche Kunstakademie D\u00fcsseldorf in 1961. The year after, he began to associate with Fluxus artists, principally Nam June Paik and George Maciunas, and later he met Minimalist artist Robert Morris. He helped to organize the Festum Fluxorum Fluxus at the Staatliche Kunstakademie D\u00fcsseldorf in 1963, and he participated for the first time in Documenta in Kassel in 1964.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Krefeld", "artistBirthDate": "1921", "artistDeathDate": "1986"}}, "53": {"paintingDate": "2001", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/2001.72_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Mixed media on canvas", "paintingName": "Daddy, Daddy, Daddy", "paintingNo": 53, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Mark Bradford", "artistBirthCountry": "", "biography": "Born in Los Angeles in 1961, Mark Bradford earned a BFA in 1995 and an MFA in 1997 from the California Institute of the Arts, Valencia. From a young age, Bradford worked in his mother\u2019s salon and referred to himself as a \u201cbeauty operator,\u201d continuing to do so even as he earned recognition in the visual arts. Bradford\u2019s early work often incorporated the tools of his trade, including singed permanent-wave endpapers, cellophane hair color, and human hair. In collage paintings like Daddy, Daddy, Daddy (2001), Bradford overlaid the translucent endpapers parallel to one another, their burned edges forming an imperfect, all-over grid. The corporeal mediums and delicate colors create a sense of intimacy and even nostalgia. However, this large-scale work\u2019s burnt materials and compulsive, labor-intensive process could appear threatening, as reminders of a culturally mandated beauty regime. Though the composition is abstract, the materials evoke elements of Bradford\u2019s personal narrative as well as the social and political significance of hair styling\u2014especially hair straightening\u2014in the black community. \nIn the mid-2000s, Bradford expanded his focus to examine the broader economic and racial geography of the communities in which he lived. In works like Black Venus (2005) and Scorched Earth (2006), he created imaginative maps of affluent black neighborhoods. The densely textured, vibrantly colored surfaces are built up from materials salvaged from the artist\u2019s Los Angeles neighborhood and collaged into exploded grids that recall both the vernacular abstraction of mapmaking as well as the utopian abstractions of the modernists. From similar materials, Bradford has also made a series of \u201cmerchant posters\u201d (2006\u2013), inspired by the advertisements hung informally around inner-city areas. In these works, layers of billboard paper overlaid on texts outlined in string have been sanded down to reveal fragments of the original phrases, and they are displayed singly or in large accumulations that recall the sites where these ads typically hang. The texts, which offer services ranging from DNA testing to expedited immigration papers, target individuals in times of personal or economic crisis and provide a window into the challenges facing urban communities. \nAlongside his work in painting and collage, Bradford has also explored issues of race, class, and gender in video, photography, sculpture, and installation. In the video Practice (2003) the artist struggles to play basketball while impeded by a modified Los Angeles Lakers uniform that includes an oversized antebellum-style hoop skirt. For Prospect.1 New Orleans (2008\u201309), the biennial organized in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, Bradford built and installed Mithra (2008), a massive ark built from shipping containers and recycled plywood fencing plastered with peeling ads, in the city\u2019s stricken Ninth Ward. In Pinocchio Is On Fire (2010), a multimedia installation created for a retrospective at the Wexner Center for the Arts, Ohio State University, Columbus, Bradford appears in the guise of a fictional character based on R & B singer Teddy Pendergrass and is featured on album covers and in musical recordings and interviews.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Los Angeles", "artistBirthDate": "1961", "artistDeathDate": ""}}, "52": {"paintingDate": "1934\u201335", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/38.432_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Oil on canvas", "paintingName": "Dining Room on the Garden", "paintingNo": 52, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Le Cannet", "artistDeathCountry": "France", "artistName": "Pierre Bonnard", "artistBirthCountry": "France", "biography": "Pierre Bonnard was born on October 3, 1867, in Fontenay-aux-Roses, France. He began law studies in Paris in 1887. That same year, Bonnard also attended the Acad\u00e9mie Julian and in 1888 entered the Ecole des Beaux-Arts, where he met Ker-Xavier Roussel and Edouard Vuillard, who became his lifelong friends. Thus Bonnard gave up law to become an artist, and, after brief military service, in 1889 he joined the group of young painters called the Nabis (the prophets), which was organized by Paul S\u00e9rusier and included Maurice Denis, Paul Ranson, Roussel, Vuillard, and others. The Nabis, influenced by Paul Gauguin and Japanese prints, experimented with arbitrary color, expressive line, a wide range of mediums, and flat, patterned surfaces.\nIn 1890 Bonnard shared a studio with Vuillard and Denis, and he began to make color lithographs. The following year he met Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec. Also in 1891 he had his first show at the Salon des Ind\u00e9pendants and in the Nabis\u2019s earliest exhibitions at Le Barc de Boutteville. Bonnard exhibited with the Nabis until they disbanded in 1900. He worked in a variety of mediums; for example, he frequently made posters and illustrations for La Revue blanche, and in 1895 he designed a stained-glass window for Louis Comfort Tiffany. His first solo show, at the Galerie Durand-Ruel in 1896, included paintings, posters, and lithographs. In 1897 Ambroise Vollard published the first of many albums of Bonnard\u2019s lithographs and illustrated books.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Fontenay-aux-Roses", "artistBirthDate": "1867", "artistDeathDate": "1947"}}, "537": {"paintingDate": "1938", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/77.2395_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum", "material": "Gouache on cardboard", "paintingName": "Composition", "paintingNo": 537, "paintingLocationPlace": "New York", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Montevideo", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Joaqu\u00edn Torres-Garc\u00eda", "artistBirthCountry": "Uruguay", "biography": "Joaqu\u00edn Torres-Garc\u00eda was born in Montevideo, Uruguay, on July 28, 1874, to a Uruguayan mother and a Catalan emigrant father. Although he is considered the father of Latin American Constructivism, he spent over 40 years of his life in the United States and Europe. Due to financial difficulties, his father moved the family to his homeland of Catalonia, Spain, in June 1891. It was there, in the town of Matar\u00f3, that Torres-Garc\u00eda studied drawing at the Escuela municipal de artes y oficios de Matar\u00f3 and painting under the artist Josep Vinardell. While he was a student there, he painted in oil, executing landscapes, interiors, and still lifes. In 1892 his family moved to Barcelona, where he attended the Academia de bellas artes before enrolling in the more prestigious Academia Baixas, and frequented the avant-garde artist caf\u00e9 Els Quatre Gats, which was the haunt of writers, intellectuals, and artists such as Pablo Picasso. During this time he made the acquaintance of the architect Antoni Gaud\u00ed, with whom he collaborated, from about 1903 to 1907, on the Templo expiatorio de la Sagrada Familia and the stained glass windows of the cathedral of Palma de Mallorca.\nIn 1918 he started to design wood toys as an extension of his teaching assignments; these toys integrated very simple forms into highly complex constructions, an early example of what he would do in his later Constructivist art production. He continued to design them after his move to New York in 1920, and they were manufactured for sale in 1922 after he returned to Europe that year. He settled in Paris in 1926, and after a rejection from the 1928 Salon d'automne, began to experiment with Constructivism, creating his first truly Constructivist works in 1929. His mature work from this latter period delicately balances natural and plastic elements, often containing signs that reference the indigenous cultures of South America. Late in 1929, Torres-Garc\u00eda met Piet Mondrian, and along with Michel Seuphor the three later founded the movement Cercle et Carr\u00e9 (Circle and Square). The group went public in 1930 with an eponymous journal and a group exhibition of 46 Constructivist artists at Galerie 23, Paris. The main goal of Cercle et Carr\u00e9 was to provide an artistic alternative to the dominant Parisian movement of Surrealism, and the association served as a forum for abstract artists to explore their ideas. Torres-Garc\u00eda ultimately left the group in 1930 after several disagreements with Seuphor.\nAfter a short period of time in Madrid, where he exhibited, taught, and gave lectures, Torres-Garc\u00eda returned to Uruguay in April 1934. There he founded the Asociaci\u00f3n de arte constructivo (Association of Constructivist Artists) and published the journal Circulo y cuadrado, which introduced the avant-garde art movements of Cubism, Neoplasticism, and Constructivism to artists in his home country. He published extensively on the theory of art, and partly due to his 1935 call for artists to invert the traditional hierarchy of art by placing Latin America before Europe in his text Escuela del sur (School of the South), has many Latin American followers.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Montevideo", "artistBirthDate": "1874", "artistDeathDate": "1949"}}, "536": {"paintingDate": "1989", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/GBM1997.11_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Guggenheim Museum Bilbao", "material": "Mixed media on canvas", "paintingName": "Ambroisia", "paintingNo": 536, "paintingLocationPlace": "Bilbao", "artist": {"artistNo": 1, "artistDeathPlace": "Barcelona", "artistDeathCountry": "", "artistName": "Antoni T\u00e0pies", "artistBirthCountry": "", "biography": "Antoni T\u00e0pies was born on December 13, 1923, in Barcelona. His adolescence was disrupted by the Spanish Civil War and a serious illness that lasted two years. T\u00e0pies began to study law in Barcelona in 1944 but two years later devoted himself exclusively to art. He was essentially self-taught as a painter; the few art classes he attended left little impression on him. Shortly after becoming an artist, he began attending clandestine meetings of Els Blaus (the Blues, formed in 1946), an iconoclastic group of Catalan artists and writers. They were the precursors to Dau al Set (Seventh face of the die, 1948\u201353), which produced an eponymous review (54 issues, 1948\u201356).\nT\u00e0pies\u2019s early work was influenced by the art of Max Ernst, Paul Klee, and Joan Mir\u00f3, and by Eastern philosophy. His art was exhibited for the first time in the controversial Salo d\u2019Octubre, Barcelona, in 1948. He soon developed a recognizable personal style related to mati\u00e9risme (matter art), or Art Informel, a movement that focused on the materials of art making. The approach resulted in textural richness, but its more important aim was exploring the transformative qualities of matter. T\u00e0pies freely adopted bits of detritus, earth, and stone\u2014mediums that evoke solidity and mass\u2014in his large-scale works.\nIn 1950, his first solo show was held at the Galeries Laietanes, Barcelona, and he was included in the Pittsburgh International (now Carnegie International). The same year, the French government awarded T\u00e0pies a scholarship that enabled him to spend a year in Paris. His first solo show in New York was presented in 1953 at the gallery of Martha Jackson, who arranged for his work to be shown the following year in various galleries around the United States. During the 1950s and 1960s, T\u00e0pies exhibited in major museums and galleries throughout the United States, Europe, Japan, and South America. In 1966, he began a collection of writings, La practica de l\u2019art (The practice of art). In 1969, the book Fr\u00e8goli, a collaboration with poet Joan Brossa, was published; a second joint effort, Nocturn matinal (Morning night), appeared the following year. T\u00e0pies received the Rubens Prize of Siegen, West Germany, in 1972.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Barcelona", "artistBirthDate": "1923", "artistDeathDate": "2012"}}, "535": {"paintingDate": "1967", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/2012.95_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. While attending lyc\u00e9e during the 1910s, he met Pierre Matisse, his future dealer and lifelong friend. In 1918 he joined the Merchant Marine and traveled to Africa, South America, and England. During military service at Lun\u00e9ville in 1920, Tanguy became a friend of the poet Jacques Pr\u00e9vert. He returned to Paris in 1922 after volunteer service in Tunis and began sketching caf\u00e9 scenes that were praised by Maurice de Vlaminck. After Tanguy saw Giorgio de Chirico\u2019s work in 1923, he decided to become a painter. In 1924, he, Pr\u00e9vert, and Marcel Duhamel moved into a house that was to become a gathering place for the Surrealists. Tanguy became interested in Surrealism in 1924, when he saw the periodical La R\u00e9volution surr\u00e9aliste. Andr\u00e9 Breton welcomed him into the Surrealist group the following year.\nDespite his lack of formal training, Tanguy\u2019s art developed quickly and his mature style emerged by 1927. His first solo show was held in 1927 at the Galerie Surr\u00e9aliste in Paris. In 1928 he participated with Jean Arp, Max Ernst, Andr\u00e9 Masson, Joan Mir\u00f3, Pablo Picasso, and others in the Surrealist exhibition at the Galerie au Sacre du Printemps, Paris. Tanguy incorporated into his work the images of geological formations he had observed during a trip to Africa in 1930. He exhibited extensively during the 1930s in solo and Surrealist group shows in New York, Brussels, Paris, and London.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Paris", "artistBirthDate": "1900", "artistDeathDate": "1955"}}, "531": {"paintingDate": "1937", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/76.2553.95_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. While attending lyc\u00e9e during the 1910s, he met Pierre Matisse, his future dealer and lifelong friend. In 1918 he joined the Merchant Marine and traveled to Africa, South America, and England. During military service at Lun\u00e9ville in 1920, Tanguy became a friend of the poet Jacques Pr\u00e9vert. He returned to Paris in 1922 after volunteer service in Tunis and began sketching caf\u00e9 scenes that were praised by Maurice de Vlaminck. After Tanguy saw Giorgio de Chirico\u2019s work in 1923, he decided to become a painter. In 1924, he, Pr\u00e9vert, and Marcel Duhamel moved into a house that was to become a gathering place for the Surrealists. Tanguy became interested in Surrealism in 1924, when he saw the periodical La R\u00e9volution surr\u00e9aliste. Andr\u00e9 Breton welcomed him into the Surrealist group the following year.\nDespite his lack of formal training, Tanguy\u2019s art developed quickly and his mature style emerged by 1927. His first solo show was held in 1927 at the Galerie Surr\u00e9aliste in Paris. In 1928 he participated with Jean Arp, Max Ernst, Andr\u00e9 Masson, Joan Mir\u00f3, Pablo Picasso, and others in the Surrealist exhibition at the Galerie au Sacre du Printemps, Paris. Tanguy incorporated into his work the images of geological formations he had observed during a trip to Africa in 1930. He exhibited extensively during the 1930s in solo and Surrealist group shows in New York, Brussels, Paris, and London.\n", "artistBirthPlace": "Paris", "artistBirthDate": "1900", "artistDeathDate": "1955"}}, "530": {"paintingDate": "1931", "paintingMaterial": "", "url": "http://annex.guggenheim.org/collections/media/thumbnails/76.2553.94_ph_web.jpg", "paintingLocation": "Solomon R. While attending lyc\u00e9e during the 1910s, he met Pierre Matisse, his future dealer and lifelong friend. In 1918 he joined the Merchant Marine and traveled to Africa, South America, and England. During military service at Lun\u00e9ville in 1920, Tanguy became a friend of the poet Jacques Pr\u00e9vert.
